questionOriginal: What is serologic, or antibody, testing and will it be used in Vermont?
questionText: What is serologic, or antibody, testing and will it be used in Vermont?
answerOriginal:
Serologic testing measures antibodies in the blood of a person who has been infected with COVID-19, whether they felt sick or not. In other words, it measures the bodyâs immune response to the virus, but does not detect the virus itself. According to the FDA, in the early days of an infection when the bodyâs immune response is still building, antibodies may not be detected. This limits the testâs effectiveness for diagnosing COVID-19 and why it should not be used as the sole basis to diagnose COVID-19.

With any test, there is always a risk of incorrect test results â false positive and false negative results. We need a good and accurate test we can rely on. The Vermont Department of Health convened a working group of experts to research antibody tests. Their findings conclude that at this time, the serologic (antibody) tests that are currently available are not accurate or reliable enough. Based on these findings, they caution against using serologic testing to make decisions about individuals. For example, using this test to establish âproof of immunity.â However, this type of test could help us better understand the population-level rate of infection from COVID-19 in Vermont.

We will continue to use public health best practice â considering clinical data, exposure history, and what is happening at the community-level â to make decisions on when to reopen businesses and when to return to work. The working group will continue to meet regularly and will be watching closely for changes and improvements in serologic testing. Recommendations may change based on new data.
answerText:
Serologic testing measures antibodies in the blood of a person who has been infected with COVID-19, whether they felt sick or not. In other words, it measures the bodyâs immune response to the virus, but does not detect the virus itself.
With any test, there is always a risk of incorrect test results â false positive and false negative results. We need a good and accurate test we can rely on. The Vermont Department of Health convened a working group of experts to research antibody tests. Their findings conclude that at this time, the serologic (antibody) tests that are currently available would not produce results that are accurate or reliable enough in Vermont. The working group will continue to meet regularly and will be watching closely for changes and improvements in serologic testing. Recommendations may change based on new data.
Though certain providers may offer antibody testing in Vermont, the working group cautions against using serologic testing to make decisions about individuals, for example, using this test to establish âproof of immunity.â However, this type of test could help us better understand the population-level rate of infection from COVID-19 in Vermont.

questionOriginal: What is a PCR test?
questionText: What is a PCR test?
answerOriginal:
A PCR test is the most common type of COVID-19 test used today. PCR stands for polymerase chain reaction. The test identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus.

PCR tests are generally the most reliable tests. Samples are analyzed at a lab, which usually takes up to a few days. A PCR test is used at pop-up testing sites offered by the Health Department.

Data on COVID-19 activity reported by the Health Department includes only PCR tests.

The PCR test used by the Vermont Department of Health Laboratory has a sensitivity rate of 95%, which means the test correctly gives a positive result 95% of the time. Sensitivity rates may be different at other labs.

questionOriginal: Why is it okay to end quarantine after seven days with a negative test result?
questionText: Why is it okay to end quarantine after seven days with a negative test result?
answerOriginal: Studies have found most people will develop symptoms by Day 7. This why there is the option for people to be tested at Day 7 or after in their quarantine and, if the test is negative, to end quarantine. The test must be a PCR test.
answerText: Studies have found most people will develop symptoms by Day 7. This why there is the option for people to be tested at Day 7 or after in their quarantine and, if the test is negative, to end quarantine. The test must be a PCR test.

questionOriginal: Do I need a negative COVID-19 test result to return to work safely?
questionText: Do I need a negative COVID-19 test result to return to work safely?
answerOriginal:
A negative test for COVID-19 should NOT be required to return to work. The Health Department does not issue letters for employees to return to work either.

The best way to know when itâs safe for someone who tested positive for COVID-19 to return to work is to follow guidance based on the presence of symptoms, or the amount of time that has passed since the person was tested. This information is found in the employer guidance, under âWhen can employees with COVID-19 return to work?â

questionOriginal: When can I stop self-isolating (home isolation)?
questionText: When can I stop self-isolating (home isolation)?
answerOriginal:
People with COVID-19 who have stayed home (home isolated) can stop home isolation under the following conditions:

If you will not have a test to determine if you are still contagious, you can leave home after these three things have happened:

  • you have had no fever for at least 72 hours (that is three full days of no fever without the use medicine that reduces fevers) AND

  • other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND

  • at least 10 days have passed since your symptoms first appeared

If you will be tested to determine if you are still contagious, you can leave home after these three things have happened:

  • you no longer have a fever (without the use medicine that reduces fevers) AND

  • other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND

  • you received two negative tests in a row, 24 hours apart.

Your doctor will follow CDC guidelines. In all cases, follow the guidance of your health care provider and the Health Department. The decision to stop home isolation should be made in consultation with your health care provider and the Health Department.
answerText:
People with COVID-19 who have stayed home (home isolated) can stop home isolation under the following conditions:
If you had symptoms, you can leave home and be with others after these three things have happened (unless otherwise instructed by your health care provider:

you have had no fever for at least 24 hours without the use medicine that reduces fevers AND
other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND
at least 10 days have passed since your symptoms first appeared

If you did not have any symptoms, you can leave home and be with others after:

10 days have passed since the date you had your positive test (unless otherwise instructed by your health care provider).

Your health care provider will follow CDC guidelines. In all cases, follow the guidance of your health care provider and the Health Department. The decision to stop home isolation should be made in consultation with your health care provider and the Health Department.
After stopping home isolation, continue to follow the general precautions to help keep the virus from spreading:Â wear aÂ cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others you donât live with, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.

questionOriginal: Can I wear a face shield instead of a face mask or covering?
questionText: Can I wear a face shield instead of a face mask or covering?
answerOriginal:
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part of your household. In private settings with people you donât live with, we recommend that you wear a face mask or covering when itâs not possible to stay 6 feet apart. However, for some people, and in some cases, a face shield may be an option.

The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person, by respiratory droplets released when an infected person talks, coughs, or sneezes. Face shields are typically used in health care settings to protect the person wearing it from droplets getting into their eyes. Face masks or coverings, like a cloth face mask or bandanna, do a better job than face shields of keeping droplets in and not spreading the virus.

If you have trouble breathing or if you work in a setting where it is difficult to wear a face mask or covering, wearing a face shield is better than wearing nothing over your nose and mouth. People who have trouble breathing can also wear a light-weight bandanna or cloth covering tied to be open at the bottom. In school settings, students and adults are allowed to wear face shields, and in child care settings, providers, teachers and staff are allowed to wear face shields.

Face shields should extend below the chin, to the ears on both sides, and there should be no exposed gap between the forehead and the shieldâs headpiece. Clean them regularly â especially if condensation or droplets are visible on the inside of the shield â and handle them like face masks or coverings when putting them on or removing them. (see âWhat is the correct way to wear a face mask or covering?â on this page for more details).

questionOriginal: Can you tell me more information about a person diagnosed with COVID-19?
questionText: Can you tell me more information about a person diagnosed with COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
In order to protect a personâs personal health information and privacy, we canât provide details about specific cases. We are focusing our efforts on contact tracing to help identify people who have been in close contact with a person who has tested positive for COVID-19. We will keep the public informed as we are able, including any known risk to the public.

Find up-to-date COVID-19 information on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.

questionOriginal: What details can you share about people who have died from COVID-19?
questionText: What details can you share about people who have died from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Information on the deaths from COVID-19 in Vermont is available on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.

Information on the number of deaths from COVID-19 in the U.S. is available from the CDC.
answerText:
The total number of deaths across the state and for each county are updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. You can find information on how the data for deaths are reported in the notes section of the dashboard. There are also more frequently asked questions about the data above the dashboard.
Information on the number of deaths from COVID-19 in the U.S. is available from the CDC.
Weekly summaries of Vermont COVID-19 data include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What does âinfectious periodâ mean?
questionText: What does âinfectious periodâ mean?
answerOriginal:
The infectious period is the period of time when someone with COVID-19 has a high chance of spreading the virus to others. The infectious period starts two days before any symptoms began â or for people with COVID-19 who don't have symptoms, two days before they got tested â and continues until they have recovered.

People who had close interactions with the person with COVID-19 during this time are at risk and may be considered close contacts.

People who had close interactions with the person with COVID-19 during this time are at risk and may be considered close contacts.

questionOriginal: When can a person return to work if they have a symptom or multiple symptoms of COVID-19?
questionText: When can a person return to work if they have a symptom or multiple symptoms of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you are sick with any symptoms of COVID-19,

Talk with your health care provider to determine if:

  • your symptoms are due to COVID-19 or some other reason
  • you should or should not go to public places or work

If COVID-19 is suspected, your health care provider can refer you for testing. Stay home while you are waiting for your test results. If you test positive, a Health Department contact tracer will reach out to walk you through what to do next.

You will be advised to stay home from work and other activities until:

  • fever has resolved for at least 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing medications, and other symptoms (like cough or shortness of breath) have improved â AND â
  • at least 10 days have passed since symptoms first appeared.

If you are sick due to something other than COVID-19, you should stay out of work until:

  • you have been without fever for 24 hours without using fever-reducing medications (if you had a fever) â AND â
  • any other symptoms have resolved or are improving.
answerText:
If you are sick with any symptoms of COVID-19,
Talk with your health care provider to determine if:

your symptoms are due to COVID-19 or some other reason
you should or should not go to public places or work

If COVID-19 is suspected, your health care provider can refer you for testing. Stay home while you are waiting for your test results. If you test positive, a Health Department contact tracer will reach out to walk you through what to do next.
You will be advised to stay home from work and other activities until:

fever has resolved for at least 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing medications, and other symptoms (like cough or shortness of breath) have improved â AND â
at least 10 days have passed since symptoms first appeared.

If you are sick due to something other than COVID-19, you should stay out of work until:

you have been without fever for 24 hours without using fever-reducing medications (if you had a fever) â AND â
any other symptoms have resolved or are improving.

questionOriginal: How does being indoors with the windows closed affect my risk of getting COVID-19?
questionText: How does being indoors with the windows closed affect my risk of getting COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading the COVID-19 virus and becoming infected with it.

The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly through close contact from person to person, by respiratory droplets when people with COVID-19 cough, sneeze, sing, talk, or breathe.

It is possible for COVID-19 to be transmitted under certain circumstances when very small respiratory droplets remain airborne. These small particles can infect someone who is more than 6 feet away. This airborne transmission is uncommon, but can happen when inside a building without proper ventilation that has allowed a buildup of respiratory droplets or particles.

In general, the more people there are in an indoor environment, the more there is a need for ventilation with outdoor air.

There is going to be some level of risk if you are indoors with people you donât live with. The level of risk can depend on multiple things, including:

  • How big the space is â Larger rooms or areas that allow enough space for everyone to keep a 6-foot distance from others are less of a risk than small rooms or areas that can easily get crowded.
  • How many people are in the room or area â A small number of people reduces your risk compared to many people who are not able to keep a 6-foot distance from others.
  • How much ventilation there is â Open windows and doors for ventilation with outdoor air. If it is too cold outside to open windows, then setting up a fan to pull air out of the room can reduce your risk. However, using a fan to blow air into or around the room or using ceiling fans is not recommended since they could keep the virus in the air for longer.
  • How humid the room or area is - Coronaviruses thrive when the relative humidity is below 40%, which usually happens when buildings are heated during the fall and winter. If you can, run a humidifier to maintain a relative humidity of at least 40% in the room or area where people are gathering.
  • What the people are doing in the room or area â Places where people can continuously wear a mask (for example, a family gathering without food or drink or a library) are less of a risk than places where people might take their masks off (for example, dinner at a friendâs house or a restaurant).

Be sure to take these general precautions any time you are in an indoor environment, whether you are at home or in another building:

  • Stay home if you are sick.
  • Avoid crowded indoor spaces.
  • Wear a face mask or covering.
  • Keep a 6-foot distance from people you donât live with.
  • Wash your hands often.

Learn more:

  • How to increase ventilation in your home from the EPA
  • FAQs about indoor air and COVID-19 from the EPA
  • Hosting gatherings or cook-outs from the CDC
  • Attending an event or gathering from the CDC
  • Holiday celebrations from the CDC

questionOriginal: How can we safely carpool?
questionText: How can we safely carpool?
answerOriginal:
If possible, donât carpool. This is because people will be within 6 feet of each other and in an enclosed space. If you need to carpool to work, school or sports games or practices, itâs best to:

  • Wear masks at all times.
  • Limit the number of people you carpool with.
  • Carpool with the same people, ideally those who are following the COVID-19 prevention steps in their day-to-day lives.
  • Keep a log of who you and your family have carpooled with that includes dates, names of other riders, and the duration of the ride.
  • Keep the windows or vents open for fresh air.
  • Cover your coughs and sneezes.
  • Clean and disinfect surfaces often.
  • Wash or sanitize your hands before getting in and out of the car.

Do not carpool if you are sick or have been in close contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19.

Read the CDCâs tips on carpooling safely.

questionOriginal: What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation?
questionText: What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation?
answerOriginal:
• Isolation is for people who are sick with COVID-19.

  • Quarantine is for people with no symptoms and who were in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19 or are returning to Vermont from out of state for anything other than an essential purpose.

  • Self-observation is for other Vermonters who donât have symptoms of COVID-19.

For more information, see the What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation? chart.
answerText:
Isolation is when people with COVID-19 stay home, and away from other people, until they have recovered, to prevent further spread. Learn about the timeline for people with COVID-19 (with symptoms and without symptoms) from being exposed to being released from isolation.
If you test positive for COVID-19, the Health Department's team of expert contact tracers will call you to provide guidance and information on staying home. They will also ask you about your close contacts. Contact tracers call your close contacts to make sure they know to stay home and quarantine to prevent further spread. Learn more about the timeline for close contacts, from when they have may have been exposed, to when they can end quarantine.
Learn more about isolation, quarantine and self-observation and what to do if you have COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What should I do if I feel sick and think I may have COVID-19?
questionText: What should I do if I feel sick and think I may have COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to find out if you should be tested.

Follow these guidelines to help keep others from getting sick:

Isolate at home:

  • Donât leave home, except to get medical care. Call ahead before visiting a health care provider or emergency department. Wear a cloth face mask or covering if you need to leave home for medical care

  • Most people with mild illness can recover at home. While there is no specific treatment for COVID-19, you should get plenty of rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take fever-reducing medication if needed.

  • Stay in a specific room in your home and use a separate bathroom, as much as possible. Stay at least 6 feet away from others in your home at all times and wear a cloth face mask or covering if you are in the same room with them. Donât share household items.

  • Have someone else care for your pets. There have been a small number of pets, including cats and dogs, reported to be infected with the COVID-19 virus, mostly after close contact with people with COVID-19. If you must care for your pet, wear a cloth face mask or covering, and wash your hands before and after.

Daily cleaning and washing:

  • Clean and disinfect surfaces in your separate room and bathroom. Have someone else clean the other areas of your home.

  • Thoroughly wash household items, like utensils, after using.

  • Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Use alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if soap and water arenât available.

Find out what to do if you are diagnosed with COVID-19.

For more information, see CDC's guidance on what to do if you are sick.
answerText:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to find out if you should be tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
If you or a family member are sick, follow these steps to care for yourself and to help protect other people in your home and your community:

Stay home except to get medical care.
Separate yourself from other people.
Monitor your symptoms.
Call ahead before visiting your doctor.
Wear a cloth face mask or covering when youâre around people and pets.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with your sleeve or a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Wash your hands often. Use an alcohol-based sanitizer if soap and water aren't available.
Avoid sharing personal household items.
Clean all high-touch surfaces in your home daily.

Find more details on what to do if you are sick from the CDC.
Find out what to do if you are diagnosed with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What is the percent of tests positive for COVID-19 in Vermont?
questionText: What is the percent of tests positive for COVID-19 in Vermont?
answerOriginal: You can find the percent of positive tests, or positivity rate, in Vermont on the Vermont Dashboard.
answerText: You can find the percent of positive tests, or positivity rate, in Vermont on the Vermont Dashboard.

questionOriginal: How many people who have tested positive for COVID-19 are in my town or county?
questionText: How many people who have tested positive for COVID-19 are in my town or county?
answerOriginal:
You can find the number of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 by county on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. This map is updated daily.

There is also a map showing the number of Vermonters who have tested positive for COVID-19 by the town where they live. Residents of long-term care facilities and inmates at correctional facilities are included in the town of their facility when they were tested. This map is updated weekly.

The Health Department shares information for towns as a number range. This is to protect the privacy of people who have tested positive for COVID-19. If some information is made public (for example, gender, age, race, health condition, travel history), then a person could be identified, especially if the population of a town is small. This follows both federal and Vermont laws.

The COVID-19 virus is spreading throughout Vermont, and many people may have it and can spread it for up to two days before they show symptoms. It is safe to assume that the virus is in your town or community, and you should take steps to protect yourself and others.

A Weekly Summary of Vermont COVID-19 Data is also available that includes more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.
answerText:
The number of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 by county is updated daily on the Vermont Dashboard.
The number of Vermonters who have tested positive for COVID-19 by the town where they live is updated weekly on the map of cases by town.
When looking at the county or town numbers, please remember that low or no recent cases is not the same as âsafer.â We know the virus is in our communities, and we should continue to follow health guidance to slow the spread of COVID-19 â no matter where we live in or visit. The maps reflect the number of people who had a positive test. There may be people in your county or town that have COVID-19 but have not been tested.
Weekly Data Summaries include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: How many people have recovered from COVID-19 in Vermont?
questionText: How many people have recovered from COVID-19 in Vermont?
answerOriginal: The number of Vermonters who have recovered from COVID-19 is updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. There is also information on this page for how the number of people recovered is reported.
answerText:
The total number of people who have recovered from COVID-19 is updated daily on the Vermont Dashboard. You can find information on how the data for total people recovered are reported in the notes section of the dashboard. There are also more frequently asked questions about the data above the dashboard.
Weekly Data Summaries include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What does close contact mean?
questionText: What does close contact mean?
answerOriginal:
Close contact means being within 6 feet, for a long time, of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 during their infectious period, which starts two days (48 hours) before any symptoms began and continues until they are recovered. Close contact does not mean being more than 6 feet away in the same indoor environment for a long period of time, walking by, or briefly being in the same room with someone.

A âlong period of timeâ is hard to define because it depends on whether the person was sick at the time and what type of interaction you had with that person. These examples can help you determine whether you were a close contact or not.

Examples of close contacts:

  • You live in the same home.

  • You are intimate partners.

  • You rode in the same car while the person was infectious.

  • You had dinner together while the person was infectious.

Examples of not close contacts:

  • You were their cashier at the grocery store.

  • You are a pharmacist who gave the person medication.

  • You were in front of the person in line at the store.

  • You are a coworker who briefly walked by to ask a question.

A team at the Health Department works with people with COVID-19 to identify their close contacts. This is called contact tracing. The team assesses each close contact for their exposure risk and gives them health guidance and recommendations for self-isolation or other restrictions.

As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

The chart describing what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation has details about what you should do and not do, depending on your exposure risk.

Find out more about what to do if you are a close contact of someone who is diagnosed with COVID-19.
answerText:
Close contact means being within 6 feet, for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period, of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 during their infectious period. The infectious period starts two days before any symptoms began â or for people with COVID-19 who don't have symptoms, two days before they got tested â and continues until they are recovered.
Close contact does not mean being more than 6 feet away in the same indoor environment for a short period of time, walking by, or briefly being in the same room with someone.
Here are some examples:
Examples of close contacts:

You live in the same home.
You are intimate partners.
You rode in the same car while the person was infectious.
You had dinner together while the person was infectious.

Examples of not close contacts:

You were their cashier at the grocery store.
You were their server at a restaurant.
You are a pharmacist who gave the person medication.
You were in front of the person in line at the store.
You are a coworker who briefly walked by to ask a question.

If you are identified as a close contact,Â you will be contacted. The notification could come from the Health Department, your employer, school, or health care provider, for example.Â TheyÂ will call you and tell you the date when you may have been exposed. They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time. They will ask you to watch for symptoms and ask if you need any help while staying home. Learn how contact tracing for COVID-19 works in Vermont.
Consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Do I need to quarantine if someone I live with is waiting for their COVID-19 test results?
questionText: Do I need to quarantine if someone I live with is waiting for their COVID-19 test results?
answerOriginal:
You do not need to quarantine if you live with someone who is waiting for their test results only if you:

  • do not have symptoms of COVID-19.
  • have not had contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19.
  • have not traveled out of Vermont for the past 14 days.

This means that you can go to school, work, or the grocery store.

Be sure to stay at least 6 feet from the person who is under quarantine. People who are under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with others in the household who are not under quarantine. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.

If you have symptoms of COVID-19, talk with your health care provider. If you don't have a provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearestÂ federally qualified health centerÂ or one ofÂ Vermont's free & referral clinics.

questionOriginal: I am in isolation because I tested positive for COVID-19, but I can't avoid close contact with someone I take care of. Do they need to quarantine?
questionText: I am in isolation because I tested positive for COVID-19, but I can't avoid close contact with someone I take care of. Do they need to quarantine?
answerOriginal: Yes. In situations where you have COVID-19 (for example, youâre a parent) and you cannot avoid close contact with those you take care of (for example, your children), then the people you take care of should stay home and away from other people while you are sick. They should also quarantine for 14 days after you are able to end home isolation. Learn more about living with someone who has COVID-19 and cannot avoid close contact (Scenario 4).
answerText: Yes. In situations where you have COVID-19 (for example, youâre a parent) and you cannot avoid close contact with those you take care of (for example, your children), then the people you take care of should stay home and away from other people while you are sick. They should also quarantine for 14 days after you are able to end home isolation. Learn more about living with someone who has COVID-19 and cannot avoid close contact (Scenario 4).

questionOriginal: I take care of someone who is in quarantine, but I canât avoid close contact with them. Do I need to quarantine?
questionText: I take care of someone who is in quarantine, but I canât avoid close contact with them. Do I need to quarantine?
answerOriginal:
In situations where close contact cannot be avoided, close contacts of the person under quarantine do not also need to quarantine. For example, if someone under quarantine depends on another person for care and basic needs, and close contact cannot be avoided, the caregiver may continue with activities outside of the home. For example, the caregiver may continue to go to work, school, child care, the grocery store, etc.

As much as possible, continue to practice these prevention steps. Stay at least 6 feet from the person who is under quarantine. People who are under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with others in the household who are not under quarantine. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.

Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from others to prevent further spread. Quarantine means staying at a home or dwelling for 14 days since the day they were potentially exposed, before doing any activities outside of the home. People in quarantine should separate themselves from others and check themselves for symptoms.

questionOriginal: What is an outbreak of COVID-19?
questionText: What is an outbreak of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Outbreaks have different definitions depending on the setting in which they occur, including community, educational, congregate living or workplace settings. They can be two or more cases that are epidemiologically connected.

Learn more about what an outbreak means, when they are considered resolved, how many have happened in each type of setting, plus find more data on outbreaks that have happened in Vermont in our Weekly Data Summary.
answerText:
The Health Department refers to âsituationsâ when one person who tested positive for COVID-19 was at a setting (for example, at school, their work place, or a health care facility) or an event (for example, a private party) while they were infectious and there is a concern that the virus could spread to others who attended the event or who were present at the setting. Situations usually require more follow up than only notifying close contacts. The Health Department monitors situations but does not report any data on them.
However, a situation may become an outbreak. An outbreak means that the virus has spread to more than one person associated with the setting or the event. Learn more about what an outbreak means, when they are considered resolved, how many have happened in each type of setting, plus find more data on outbreaks that have happened in Vermont in our Weekly Data Summary.

questionOriginal: What do I do if I believe I had close contact with someone who has COVID-19?
questionText: What do I do if I believe I had close contact with someone who has COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you have been in close contact with a person who tested positive for COVID-19, monitor yourself for symptoms. This includes checking your temperature every day, watching for symptoms and staying home.

If you develop symptoms of COVID-19 and are a close contact of someone who tested positive, you should:

  1. Call your health care provider and

  2. Call the Vermont Department of Health at 802-863-7240.

If you do not develop symptoms, you do not need to call the Health Department.

Read what to do if you're a close contact of someone with COVID-19.
answerText:
When someone tests positive for COVID-19, the Health Department works with them to identify their close contacts. Generally, these are people you were within 6 feet of, for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period, during the time they were infectious (contagious).
If you are identified as a close contact, you will be contacted. The notification will come from the Health Department or a place you went to recently (for example, your employer, your childâs school, or your health care provider might contact you). They will contact you and tell you the date when you may have been exposed. They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time. They will ask you to watch for symptoms and ask if you need any help while staying home.
If you receive a textÂ message from 89361, this is a notification from the Health Department that you are a close contact of someone whoÂ tested positive for COVID-19. Soon you will receive a call from aÂ Health Department Contact Tracer.Â Find out what you need to do if you are a close contact.
If you are not identified as a close contact, then you will not be called. While contact tracers work to identify all close contacts, all might not be identified. If you think that you might be a close contact but didn't get a call, you may take precautions by quarantining for 14 days since the last day you were in contact with that person, and get tested on day 7 or after if you have not had any symptoms.
If you are not a close contact of a person who tested positive, you can continue to follow the prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.

Learn more about why, how and when to do these things.
Learn how contact tracing for COVID-19 works in Vermont.

questionOriginal: What is contact tracing?
questionText: What is contact tracing?
answerOriginal:
Contact tracing is a strategy used to determine the source of an infection and how it is spreading. Finding people who are close contacts to a person who has tested positive for COVID-19, and therefore at higher risk of becoming infected themselves, can help prevent further spread of the virus.

A team of callers tries to reach anyone who has tested positive for COVID-19. They ask the patient questions about their activities within a certain timeframe â to help identify anyone they had close contact with. (Close contact means being closer than six feet apart for a long time while the person was infectious.) Those contacts might include family members, co-workers or health care providers. Please note, the Health Department only uses a live person for contact tracing and never uses anything that sounds like a âroboâ (computer-generated voice) call.

The team then gets in touch with those contacts and provides health guidance on what to do if you are a close contact of someone who is diagnosed with COVID-19. A close contact is asked to stay home for 14 days and watch for symptoms.

While we have been successful in contact tracing, we will continue to add resources and personnel needed to address any increase in the number of people who test positive, which we expect to happen with more testing. This includes the use of technology to help in these efforts. We will be using an app called SARA Alert, a secure monitoring and reporting system for public health that is being used in other states. This system will allow us to offer people who have tested positive for COVID-19, and their close contacts, to enroll in a text-based system to help us keep in touch and monitor their symptoms.

As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.
answerText:
Contact tracing is used to provide education, support and guidance to people who are diagnosed with an infectious disease. Itâs also used to identify people who have been in close contact with them, so they can take steps to stop the disease from spreading to others.
If you test positive for COVID-19, you will get a call from the Health Department. A trained public health worker, called a contact tracer, will give you guidance to stay home and away from other people until you recover. This stops the virus from spreading to other people. They will ask you questions about your symptoms, activities, and who you may have come into contact with during a specific period of time. This information is only used to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
If you are identified as a close contact, you will be contacted. The notification will come from the Health Department or a place you went to recently (for example, your employer, your childâs school, or your health care provider might contact you). They will contact you and tell you the date when you may have been exposed. They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time. They will ask you to watch for symptoms and ask if you need any help while staying home.
If you receive a text message from 89361, this is a notification from the Health Department that you are a close contact of someone who tested positive for COVID-19. Soon you will receive a call from a Health Department Contact Tracer. Find out what you need to do if you are a close contact.
Itâs important to answer the call and to answer questions as completely as possible to make sure everyone knows what steps to take to prevent further spread of the virus. Governor Scottâs Executive Order calls on Vermonters to comply with all contact tracing requests.
All restaurants and other businesses are keeping a 30-day log of employee and guest names and contact information in case contact tracing is needed.
Consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.
Currently, Vermont is not participating in the contact tracing notifications that are available on some cell phones. We are waiting to see how successful this service is in other states who are participating. If itâs proven to be effective, we will consider using it.
Learn how contact tracing for COVID-19 works in Vermont.

questionOriginal: Why are rates used on the town map, and how are they calculated?
questionText: Why are rates used on the town map, and how are they calculated?
answerOriginal:
The rate of recent cases by town map reflects the rate of cases of COVID-19 among Vermont residents per 10,000 people, by town of residence, from the past two weeks. Rates are commonly used because they allow us to compare the number of cases across towns that have different population sizes.

To calculate the rate by town in the last two weeks, we take the number of cases reported in the last two weeks in a town and divide it by that townâs population. That number is multiplied by 10,000 people. This is the rate, or number of cases per 10,000 people.

Use the map to compare how prevalent COVID-19 is in a town over the past two weeks, relative to other towns. The map may help communities assess how their town is doing and take additional actions to prevent the spread of COVID-19 when necessary.

When looking at the town rates, please remember that having a lower rate of recent cases is not the same as âsafer.â We know the virus is in our communities, and we should continue to follow health guidance to slow the spread of COVID-19 â no matter where we live or where we visit. The data reflect the rate of people who had a positive test. There may be people in your town that have COVID-19 but have not been tested.

questionOriginal: How is a sample collected for COVID-19 testing?
questionText: How is a sample collected for COVID-19 testing?
answerOriginal:
Usually a health care provider collects samples (specimens) from you in one of two ways, but there are other options:

  1. The health care provider collects a nasal, or nasopharyngeal (NP) swab. This is when a dry swab is inserted through one nostril and is rubbed against the back of your nose and throat.
  2. The health care provider collects a sample from the front of your nose with a dry swab.
answerText:
Usually, samples (specimens) are collected from you in one of two ways:

Nasal swab - this is a short, dry swab that is used to collect a sample from the front of your nose. This type of test is used at the Health Departmentâs testing sites. It is also used for certain priority groups, including children.
Nasopharyngeal or NP swab â this is a long, dry swab that is inserted through one nostril and is rubbed against the back of your nose and throat.

questionOriginal: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?
questionText: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
People with COVID-19 have had a wide range of symptoms reported â ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness. These symptoms may appear 2 to 14 days after exposure to the virus:

  • Fever

  • Cough

  • Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing

  • Chills

  • Repeated shaking with chills

  • Muscle pain

  • Sore throat

  • New loss of taste or smell

You can check your symptoms with the CDC's self-checker tool.

Call your health care professional if you develop symptoms and ask if a test can be considered. Learn more about COVID-19.
answerText:
People with COVID-19 have had a wide range of symptoms reported â ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness. Symptoms may start 2 to 14 days after exposure to the virus. People with these symptoms may have COVID-19:

Fever (100.4Â°F or greater)
Cough
Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
Chills
Fatigue
Muscle or body aches
Headache
New loss of taste or smell
Sore throat
Congestion or runny nose
Nausea or vomiting
Diarrhea

This list does not include all possible symptoms. The CDC will continue to update the list of symptoms as more is learned. You can check your symptoms with the CDC's self-checker tool.
Not everyone with COVID-19 has a fever. Even mild symptoms (like a headache or dry cough) could be signs of COVID-19.
Not everyone infected with the COVID-19 virus has symptoms. People with COVID-19 who don't have any symptoms can spread the virus to other people. Learn how to protect yourself and others.
All Vermonters, even with mild symptoms, are encouraged to contact their health care provider to get tested. Your provider will test you at their office or refer you for testing nearby. Stay home while waiting for your result.
If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
Learn more about what to do if you have COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What kind of assistance will be available at my vaccine appointment? Can someone come with me?
questionText: What kind of assistance will be available at my vaccine appointment? Can someone come with me?
answerOriginal:
All vaccine clinics will be handicap accessible. Wheelchairs are available at all Health Department vaccination sites and at hospitals.

Language interpreters (including ASL) can be arranged at Health Department vaccination sites. Usually, the interpreter will work with you remotely by phone or video conference through a computer available at the site. To request an interpreter, ask one of the public health workers at the site. Some sites, including Burlington and Winooski, will have in-person interpreters based on demand for these services in the area.

If you need physical assistance getting to your vaccine appointment, you can have one other person come with you. You will both have your temperatures taken and will be asked questions to determine if you have any current COVID-19 symptoms. If either of you do, then the person who has symptoms wonât be allowed to go any further.

You will both need to wear masks during your appointment. If you do not have one, there will be masks available at the clinic. If you have trouble breathing, are unable to remove your mask by yourself, or have a medical reason for not wearing one, you will not be required to wear a mask.

Find out what to do if you need a ride to your appointment.

questionOriginal: Should I get the vaccine if I have a medical condition?
questionText: Should I get the vaccine if I have a medical condition?
answerOriginal:
In clinical studies, COVID-19 vaccines were just as effective for people with and without medical conditions. In fact, people with some conditions are more likely to get very sick if they get COVID-19, so getting vaccinated could be even more important. If you are unsure if you should get the vaccine, talk to your health care provider about any conditions you have. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.

Learn more about vaccination if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.

Read the health screening questions asked before you get the vaccine.

questionOriginal: Should I be vaccinated if I have or had COVID-19?
questionText: Should I be vaccinated if I have or had COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you had COVID-19 and are recovered, you may be vaccinated or choose to defer for up to 90 days. Evidence suggests that getting infected again in 90 days after is uncommon.

If you currently have COVID-19, please wait until you have recovered before being vaccinated.

If you had monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma as part of COVID-19 treatment, wait for at least 90 days before getting your vaccination to avoid interfering with your treatment.
answerText:
If you had COVID-19 and are recovered, you may be vaccinated or choose to defer for up to 90 days. Evidence suggests that getting infected again in 90 days after is uncommon.
If you currently have COVID-19, please wait until you have recovered before being vaccinated.
If you had monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma as part of COVID-19 treatment, wait for at least 90 days before getting your vaccination to avoid interfering with your treatment.

questionOriginal: What is a âprobable caseâ?
questionText: What is a âprobable caseâ?
answerOriginal:
A case is considered âprobableâ if the person:

  • tested positive on an antigen test and has symptoms of COVID-19 or epidemiologic evidence, or
  • has symptoms of COVID-19 and is epidemiologically linked to a confirmed case of COVID-19.

As of December 2, probable cases are included in the number of COVID-19 cases in Vermont.

The Health Department follows the nationally recognized definition of COVID-19 cases, developed by the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists (CSTE) in April 2020. Since then, the Health Department has tracked probable cases and taken the same public health actions as if they were a confirmed case (confirmed means the person tested positive on a PCR test).

This means that contact tracers conduct interviews with people who are considered probable cases, provide isolation guidance, and their close contacts are notified to quarantine. People who are considered probable cases are also encouraged to get a follow-up PCR test. If they test positive on a follow-up PCR test, they are only included once in the total case count.

The Health Department began including probable cases in case counts to more accurately represent COVID-19 activity and because antigen testing in Vermont is increasing. The impact on the total case count is minimal. At this time, about 120 cases, or 2.8%, of total cases are probable cases. Right now, this change does not impact hospitalization or testing data.

Read the full CSTE definition of probable case.
answerText:
A case is considered âprobableâ if the person:

has symptoms of COVID-19 and is epidemiologically linked to a confirmed case of COVID-19.

As of December 2, probable cases are included in the number of COVID-19 cases in Vermont.
As of January 4, deaths among probable cases are included in the number of COVID-19 deaths in Vermont. A death among a probable case is a person who:

meets the probable case definition and has COVID-19 listed as a cause or contributing condition on their death certificate or
has COVID-19 listed as a cause or contributing condition on their death certificate.

The Health Department follows the nationally recognized definition of COVID-19 cases, developed by the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists (CSTE) in April 2020. People who are considered probable cases are also encouraged to get a follow-up PCR test. If they test positive on a follow-up PCR test, they are only included once in the total case count.
The Health Department began including probable cases and deaths in counts to more accurately represent COVID-19 activity and because antigen testing in Vermont is increasing. Right now, this change does not impact hospitalization or testing data.

questionOriginal: What is the correct way to wear a face mask or covering?
questionText: What is the correct way to wear a face mask or covering?
answerOriginal:
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part your household. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces and group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes).

Wearing face masks or coverings helps keep people from spreading the virus. This is because the virus can spread even if a person does not have any symptoms.

In addition to wearing cloth face masks or coverings, everyone should keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash their hands often, and stay home if they are sick.

A face mask or covering must be worn properly to be effective and avoid the spread of germs:

  • Wash your hands before putting it on.
  • Be sure your mouth and nose are covered.
  • Hook loops around your ears or tie it snugly.
  • Do not touch it or pull it down while in public.
  • Keep it on until you get home.
  • Remove it without touching your eyes, nose or mouth, then wash your hands immediately.
  • Wash it and make sure itâs completely dry before using again. Have a few on hand so you can rotate for washing.

If you feel like you are overheating and are having trouble breathing because it is hot outside, you should take off your mask, drink water, rest and seek shade or a cool place. It is important that you keep a 6-foot distance from others whenever possible, especially when you are not wearing a mask.

Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19 and face coverings for children.
answerText:
You are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces (for example, businesses, public buildings, parks), group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes), and other places where itâs not possible to stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
In private settings (for example, at a gathering with family and friends in your backyard or riding in a car), we recommend that you wear a mask anytime you're around people you donât live with.
People with COVID-19 can spread the virus even if they donât have any symptoms. Masks protect others around you as well as offer some protection to you.
A mask must be worn properly to be effective and avoid spreading the virus:

Wash your hands or use hand sanitizer before putting it on.
Put it over your nose and mouth and secure it under your chin.
Make sure it fits snugly against the side of your face.
Slip the loops over your ears or tie the strings behind your head.
Do not touch it when you are wearing it.
Remove it by handling only the ear loops or ties and fold the outside corners together.
Be careful not to touch your eyes, nose or mouth, then wash your hands immediately after removing it.

Wash your mask regularly and make sure itâs completely dry before using it again. Have a few on hand so you can rotate them for washing and have enough clean ones to wear.
During hot weather, if you feel like you are overheating and are having trouble breathing because it is hot, take off your mask, drink water, rest and seek shade or a cool place. It is important that you stay at least 6 feet away from others whenever possible, especially when you are not wearing a mask.
During cold weather, change your mask when it becomes wet. Keep a spare mask to replace the wet one, and put the wet one in a plastic bag until you get home. If you need to wear a scarf, ski mask or balaclava, wear it over your mask. If you wear glasses, find a mask that fits closely over your nose or has a nose wire to help reduce fogging.
Wearing masks is one way we can help slow the spread of COVID-19 â in addition to staying at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with and other prevention steps.
Learn more:

Wearing face masks to keep COVID-19 from spreading
Face coverings for children
How to select, clean and wear your face mask

The State of Vermont is offering a limited number of free cloth face masks to the public. Find out if free cloth face masks are available in your area.

questionOriginal: What can I expect at my vaccine appointment?
questionText: What can I expect at my vaccine appointment?
answerOriginal:
You will need to wear a mask during your appointment. If you do not have one, there will be one available for you at the clinic. If you have trouble breathing, are unable to remove it yourself, or have a medical reason for not wearing one, you will not be required to wear a mask.

Remember to dress warmly for the weather.Â Arrive on time so you donât have to wait long, or keep others waiting.Â Please do not arrive earlier than 15 minutes before your appointment. If you need someone to come with you for assistance, please only bring one person so we can limit the number of people inside the clinics and make sure people are properly distanced.

Once you arrive at the vaccine clinic, here is what will happen:

  1. Before you enter the clinic, someone will take your temperature and ask questions to determine if you have any current symptoms of COVID-19. If you do, then you will be asked to reschedule your appointment.
  2. You will go inside and check in. You will be asked to fill out paperwork, which will include a health screening questionnaire.
  3. You will be asked to go to a vaccination station where you will get the vaccine in your arm.
  4. You will be given a handout with information about the vaccine you got and any possible side effects to watch out for, as well as how to report any reactions or side effects you may have.
  5. You will be asked to stay for 15 to 30 minutes so you can be watched for any side effects.
  6. Someone will help you schedule an appointment to get your second dose of vaccine at a later date.

You will need to wear a mask during your appointment. If you do not have one, there will be one available for you at the clinic. If you have trouble breathing, are unable to remove it yourself, or have a medical reason for not wearing one, you will not be required to wear a mask.

You will be asked to go to a vaccination station where you will get the vaccine in your arm.
You will be given a handout with information about the vaccine you got and any possible side effects to watch out for, as well as how to report any reactions or side effects you may have.

Someone will help you schedule an appointment to get your second dose of vaccine at a later date.

questionOriginal: Does being vaccinated affect my COVID-19 test results?
questionText: Does being vaccinated affect my COVID-19 test results?
answerOriginal:
No. The COVID-19 vaccines that are available and the other vaccines currently in clinical trials in the United States will not cause you to test positive on viral tests. PCR and antigen tests are viral tests, and will tell you if you are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus.

If your body develops an immune response, which is what happens when you get vaccinated, there is a possibility you may test positive on some antibody tests. Antibody, or serologic, tests measure the bodyâs immune response to the virus and show that you may have some level of protection against the virus. Experts are currently looking at how getting the COVID-19 vaccine may affect antibody testing results.

questionOriginal: Can I make two appointments for COVID-19 vaccination at the same time, for example for both my parents or myself and my spouse?
questionText: Can I make two appointments for COVID-19 vaccination at the same time, for example for both my parents or myself and my spouse?
answerOriginal:
You will need to register each person individually. We can only register one person for an appointment at a time online and through the call center. This is because each slot and series of questions apply just to one person.

If you are making an appointment online, you can either create an account for each person, or create a single account and add the other person to the account by clicking on the âAdd Dependent/Spouseâ button at the top of the screen (follow the prompts in the registration system). You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address. Find out what you will need and how to make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

If you are making an appointment by phone, you can also make more than one appointment. We will do our best to get the appointments as close together as possible, but they may not be at the same time. Call 855-722-7878 Monday through Friday from 8:15 a.m. â 5:30 p.m. and Saturday to Sunday 10:00 a.m. â 3:00 p.m.

questionOriginal: I donât have my own transportation. Can I get a ride to my vaccine appointment?
questionText: I donât have my own transportation. Can I get a ride to my vaccine appointment?
answerOriginal:
Yes. Free public transportation to vaccine clinics is available to Vermont residents who do not have their own transportation. Rides are coordinated by the Vermont Public Transportation Association. Volunteer drivers will use cars, vans or buses. All rides are ADA compliant and will accommodate people living with disabilities.

Please make a request at least 48 hours before your vaccine appointment. These rides are subject to the availability of transportation resources, so advance notice is necessary to make sure you will have a ride.

Rides are only available if you are not sick with COVID-19 (with symptoms or without symptoms) or are not a close contact of someone who has COVID-19. If you recently traveled, you need to follow the current travel quarantine requirements before you can request a ride. If you fall into one of these categories, you will need to answer some questions to find out when you can use public transportation.

Find contact information for your local public transportation provider.

questionOriginal: I take care of someone who is in isolation because they tested positive for COVID-19, but I canât avoid close contact with them. Do I need to quarantine?
questionText: I take care of someone who is in isolation because they tested positive for COVID-19, but I canât avoid close contact with them. Do I need to quarantine?
answerOriginal: Yes. In situations where you cannot avoid close contact with someone with COVID-19, you should stay home and away from other people while the person you are caring for is sick. You should also quarantine for 14 days after they are able to end home isolation. Learn more about living with someone who has COVID-19 and cannot avoid close contact (Scenario 4).
answerText:
Yes. In situations where you cannot avoid close contact with someone with COVID-19, you should quarantine while the person you are caring for is sick. You should also quarantine for 14 days after they are able to end home isolation.
Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from other people. Quarantine means you need to stay home and away from other people for 14 days since the day you were potentially exposed. You should separate yourself from others and check yourself for symptoms. Learn about the option to be tested to end quarantine after 7 days.
Find tips on what to do when a household member is sick with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: How do I know if my symptoms are from the vaccine or sickness from COVID-19?
questionText: How do I know if my symptoms are from the vaccine or sickness from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
It takes time for the vaccine to teach your body to fight COVID-19, so you may not be protected by the vaccine until a few weeks after your second dose. This is one of the reasons it is so important to continue prevention steps, like wearing a mask, keeping 6 feet apart, and washing your hands, even after youâve been vaccinated.

It may be hard to tell the difference between side effects from the vaccine and symptoms from sickness if you get infected with COVID-19 between vaccine doses. While everyoneâs reaction may be different, vaccine side effects usually start within 12 to 24 hours after your vaccination. They should go away within a few days.

If symptoms get worse or last longer than a few days, contact your health care provider. They should be able to suggest next steps and maybe a COVID-19 test. Getting the vaccine will not affect your COVID-19 test results.

questionOriginal: What happens if a vaccine clinic is canceled due to weather?
questionText: What happens if a vaccine clinic is canceled due to weather?
answerOriginal:
Check your local news station or the Health Departmentâs website and social media (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram) for any changes to Health Department vaccine clinic schedules due to weather.

If the Health Department vaccine clinic is not canceled but youâd like to reschedule your appointment because of the weather, call 855-722-7878.

If you registered to get your vaccine at Kinney Drugs, contact the store where your appointment is to find out if the clinic will be open or how to reschedule.

No matter what, you should always watch the weather and stay home if you don't feel safe traveling. There are enough vaccine appointments for everyone who is eligible â we will get you rescheduled if needed.

questionOriginal: Can I take medicines before or after my vaccine?
questionText: Can I take medicines before or after my vaccine?
answerOriginal:
If you regularly take pain relievers like aspirin, acetaminophen (for example, Tylenol) or ibuprofen (for example, Motrin, Advil), allergy or other medications for medical conditions, please continue to do so as directed by your health care provider or as needed.

Do not take pain relievers or allergy medication before you get the vaccine to avoid side effects or allergic reactions. Allergy medications do not prevent a serious allergic reaction. They may hide symptoms that would tell a health care provider to treat an allergic reaction. Pain relievers may limit the vaccine from making a strong immune response.

After your vaccine, you can take pain relievers for any side effects you may have from the vaccine to help you feel better.

questionOriginal: What is an antigen test?
questionText: What is an antigen test?
answerOriginal:
An antigen test is a newer type of COVID-19 test that identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus.

Antigen tests provide results much more quickly than diagnostic, or PCR, tests (the most common type of test used to diagnose COVID-19 infection). But antigen tests may not be as accurate.

Antigen tests may be used to screen people to identify those who need a more definitive test.

We are monitoring how these antigen tests evolve and how results can best be used. Currently, people who test positive from antigen tests are not considered lab-confirmed cases and are not included in our total number of cases. However, we recommend they follow the same guidelines as a positive case to stay home (self-isolate). We would also conduct contact tracing and recommend a more accurate diagnostic test to confirm the positive result.

Antigen tests are different from antibody (serologic) tests, which identify people who have previously been infected with the coronavirus and do not show whether a person is currently infected.
answerText:
An antigen test for COVID-19 is a type of test that identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus. Antigen tests provide results much more quickly than PCR tests (the most common type of test used to diagnose and confirm COVID-19 infection). Antigen tests are sometimes referred to as rapid (fast) tests.
Antigen tests are usually less sensitive than PCR tests, so they might miss some cases. Antigen tests could be more useful in certain circumstances:

For people who have symptoms of COVID-19. So far, studies on antigen tests have only been done on people with symptoms, and we do not have evidence about the accuracy of the antigen test on people without symptoms.
Health care providers may use antigen testing when PCR testing is not available or when results are needed quickly. This may be when people who are having symptoms get tested at their doctorâs office or when patients are being admitted to hospitals that donât have a lot of PCR tests available.
Antigen tests may be used to screen people to identify those who need a more definitive test. Antigen tests are particularly helpful when used to test people in the early stages of infection (within the first 5 to 7 days of having COVID-19 symptoms) when the viral load is generally the highest. For example, long-term care facilities could screen residents and staff who are not having symptoms, but only if the tests were done at least weekly.
For surveillance purposes, to see what COVID-19 activity might be occurring in a community.

When used to test people with COVID-19 symptoms, antigen tests have a higher chance of missing an active infection than PCR tests. This means that if you have symptoms, you may receive a negative result but still be infected with COVID-19.
Antigen tests are different from antibody (serologic) tests, which identify people who have previously been infected with the COVID-19 virus and do not show whether a person is currently infected.
Learn more:

Use of Antigen Testing in Vermont â Health Update October 1, 2020
Coronavirus testing basics from the Food and Drug Administration
Considerations for Implementation of SARS-CoV-2 Rapid Antigen Testing from the Association of Public Health Laboratories.

questionOriginal: When will I receive my test results?
questionText: When will I receive my test results?
answerOriginal:
Test results will be available typically within 1 to 3 days.

How you receive results varies depending on where you were tested.

If you were tested at a Health Department popup testing site (for people without symptoms), you will get a call from the Health Department when your results are ready, which is usually within 2 to 4 days, if not sooner. You will also get a letter in the mail within 7 days of being tested. Health Department tests sites are listed here.

If you got tested anywhere else, the Health Department cannot provide your results. Please contact your health care provider if they ordered the test, or the facility that conducted the test.

If you received a positive result, the Health Department will also reach out to talk to you about public health recommendations and ask questions about people you were in contact with. It is possible that the Health Department may contact you before your health care provider does.
answerText:
Test results will be available typically within 3 business days. Business days are Monday through Friday. If you were tested on a Wednesday, Thursday or Friday, your results may not be posted until the following week. Holidays are not considered business days. Find out what to do while youâre waiting for your test results and how to get your results.
How you receive results varies depending on where you were tested.
If you were tested at a Health Department testing site (for people without symptoms) and:

you requested an electronic result, you can expect an email within 3 business days, when your result is ready. You can then log in to your COVID-19 testing account to get the result. You will not receive a letter.
you requested a letter, you can expect to receive it within 7 business days. If you also provided an email address, you can expect an email within 3 business days, when your result is ready. You can then log in to your COVID-19 testing account to get the result.
If you do not have a COVID-19 testing account (you attended the testing event as a walk-in) a patient ID was created for you and sent to the email you provided. You will need to use the link in the email to confirm your patient ID. Once you confirm the patient ID, you can log in to your COVID-19 testing account and view your test results once they are available, which will be within 3 business days.

Call 802-863-7240 option 9 if you are having problems accessing your test results.
The Health Department only uses a PCR test. We cannot guarantee that you will receive your results in less than 3 business days. We also cannot accommodate special requests for receiving test results or rush results. Find the list of Health Department testing sites.
If you have a positive result, our contact tracing team will talk to you about public health recommendations and ask questions about people you were in contact with. It is possible that the Health Department may contact you before your health care provider does.
If you got tested anywhere else, the Health Department cannot provide your results. Please contact your health care provider if they ordered the test, or the facility that conducted the test.
If you were tested before an inpatient or outpatient procedure, you will receive your test results before your procedure from the health care provider who is doing the procedure.
If you received a positive result, the Health Department will also reach out to talk to you about public health recommendations and ask questions about people you were in contact with. It is possible that the Health Department may contact you before your health care provider does.

questionOriginal: Why do I need two doses of the vaccine?
questionText: Why do I need two doses of the vaccine?
answerOriginal:
Both the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines require two doses, spaced about 3 to 4 weeks apart. We strongly recommend Vermonters get both doses for the highest level of protection from COVID-19.

Two doses of these vaccines are scientifically proven to be highly effective in preventing COVID-19. Since the beginning, we have followed the science. Participants in the clinical trials who did not receive both doses were not followed for a long period of time, so we do not know for sure how well or how long one dose will protect you.

A two-dose vaccine is not new. For some vaccines, like hepatitis B, shingles and HPV, two doses produce longer-lasting protection. While the first dose gets your immune system ready and offers some protection, the second dose boosts that protection by using your bodyâs new immune cells it created after the first dose. This âboosterâ increases the strength of your new antibody protection and makes it last longer.

Taking the full course of vaccine offers better protection against variants of the virus. In fact, being only partially vaccinated, for example getting only one dose of a two-dose vaccine, could increase the risk of vaccine-resistant variants of the virus that causes COVID-19. This is because the virus could be weakened with some antibody protection, but not stopped completely, creating the potential for the virus to mutate.

Some people experience stronger side effects after the second shot. Both the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines have equal doses in their first and second shots, but for some, stronger side effects are part of their bodyâs normal immune reaction to that âboostâ in protection. Common side effects reported were pain at the injection site, fever, chills, tiredness and headache. These side effects typically go away within a few days.

Whether you experience side effects or not, rest assured the vaccine is working to protect you, your family and your community.

Find out when you need to get your second shot.

questionOriginal: What should I know about side effects?
questionText: What should I know about side effects?
answerOriginal:
Side effects from the vaccine are normal signs that your body is building protection against COVID-19. They might even affect your daily activities but should go away in a few days. Common side effects are:

  • Pain, swelling or redness on the arm where you got the shot
  • Tiredness
  • Headache
  • Chills
  • Muscle or joint pain
  • Fever
  • Nausea or vomiting

What to do about side effects:

  • Call your health care or vaccine provider if side effects are worrying you or if they donât go away after a few days.
  • You can use V-safe to tell the CDC about any side effects and to get reminders for your second dose. V-safe is an optional smartphone tool that uses text messages and web surveys to provide personalized check-ins. Learn more and register for V-safe. If you donât have a smartphone, a family member can sign up for you.
  • If you have a bad reaction after getting vaccinated, you or your health care provider can report it to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS). Call 1-800-822-7967 or report it online.

Learn about why it is important to get two doses of the vaccine.
