questionOriginal: Is one type of mask better than another? Is wearing two masks better?
questionText: Is one type of mask better than another? Is wearing two masks better?
answerOriginal:
The most important thing to do is to wear a mask â period. Wearing a mask protects both you and the people around you from getting or spreading COVID-19.

There are several types of masks to choose from, including cloth, disposable, N95 and KN95.

According to the CDC, the most effective fabrics for cloth masks are:

  • tightly woven fabrics, such as cotton and cotton blends
  • breathable
  • two or three fabric layers

You can also wear a disposable mask, like a surgical or medical procedure mask, instead of a cloth mask, now that they are in greater supply. These masks may provide some additional protection.

The CDC has found that âdouble maskingâ or wearing two masks (disposable mask underneath and a cloth mask on top) can offer a better fit and provide extra protection.

Typically N95 masks should be reserved for health care workers who are at highest risk and need them most. KN95 masks are also available for the public to purchase, but make sure the mask has been approved by the Food & Drug Administration.

Whichever mask you choose, it is important to make sure it fits properly. Learn more from the CDC about improving how your mask protects you.

The CDC continues to study the effectiveness of different types of masks, and we will update our recommendations as new scientific evidence becomes available.

questionOriginal: What can I wear if my health or work environment doesn't allow me to wear a cloth face mask or covering?
questionText: What can I wear if my health or work environment doesn't allow me to wear a cloth face mask or covering?
answerOriginal:
People who have trouble breathing can wear a light-weight bandanna or cloth covering tied to be open at the bottom or a face shield. Face shields are generally not recommended because they are more for health care settings to protect the person wearing it from droplets getting into their eyes. Face masks or coverings, like a cloth face mask or bandanna, do a better job than face shields of keeping droplets in. However, if your work environment or health does not allow you to wear a cloth face mask, wearing a face shield is better than having no barrier on your nose and mouth.

Outdoor workers who are doing strenuous work that causes heavy breathing are not required to wear a cloth face mask or covering when it is hot outside. Workers should keep masks with them and wear them when they are not exerting themselves (for example talking, resting, or interacting with other co-workers or people). It is important that workers keep a 6-foot distance from others whenever possible, especially when they are not wearing a mask.
answerText:
The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly throughÂ close contact, by respiratory droplets released when people with COVID-19 cough, sneeze, sing, talk, or breathe.Â Face shields are typically used in health care settings to protect the person wearing them from droplets getting into their eyes. Masks or coverings, like a cloth mask or bandanna, do a better job than face shields of keeping droplets in and not spreading the virus.
However, if your work environment or health does not allow you to wear a mask, wearing a face shield is better than having no barrier over your nose and mouth.
Make sure your face shield fits properly. Face shields should extend below the chin, to the ears on both sides, and there should be no exposed gap between the forehead and the shieldâs headpiece. Clean them regularly â especially if condensation or droplets are visible on the inside of the shield â and handle them like masks when putting them on or removing them.

Workers should keep masks with them and wear them when they are not exerting themselves (for example talking, resting, or interacting with other co-workers or people). It is important that workers keep a 6-foot distance from others whenever possible, especially when they are not wearing a mask.

questionOriginal: I have recovered from COVID-19, but I am sick with a new illness and symptoms. When can I return to work, school or child care?
questionText: I have recovered from COVID-19, but I am sick with a new illness and symptoms. When can I return to work, school or child care?
answerOriginal:
If you develop new illness symptoms within the first 3 months of recovering from a COVID-19 infection, we do not recommend retesting. Data to date show that a person who has had and recovered from COVID-19 may have low levels of virus in their bodies for up to 3 months after diagnosis. This means that if the person who has recovered from COVID-19 is retested within 3 months of their initial infection, they may continue to have a positive test result, even though they are not spreading COVID-19.

You should still stay home when you are sick to prevent spreading illness to others. You should remain home until your symptoms have improved or are gone. If you have a fever, you should stay home until you are fever-free (without the use of fever-reducing medicine) for at least 24 hours. Contact your health care provider if you have questions or concerns.

Learn more about if people who recover from COVID-19 can be infected again and when you are considered to be recovered from COVID-19.

questionOriginal: I had COVID-19. Do I need to quarantine if I am a close contact of someone with COVID-19?
questionText: I had COVID-19. Do I need to quarantine if I am a close contact of someone with COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you had COVID-19 â and then are exposed to someone with COVID-19 (for example, you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19) â you do not need to quarantine only if:

  1. you had a positive COVID-19 test result (from a PCR or antigen test) and have met the criteria to end your isolation, and
  2. the new exposure is within the first 3 months after symptoms from your initial infection started, or within the first 3 months of your first positive test if you didnât have symptoms during your initial infection, and
  3. you have not had any COVID-19 symptoms since the new exposure.

However, you must quarantineÂ when you travel or return to Vermont under theÂ current travel guidelines and you are not allowed to gatherÂ with people you donât live with under theÂ current social gathering guidelines.

questionOriginal: How long does protection from the vaccine last?
questionText: How long does protection from the vaccine last?
answerOriginal:
According to the CDC, we donât know how long protection lasts for those who are vaccinated. What we do know is that COVID-19 has caused very serious illness and death for a lot of people. If you get COVID-19, you also risk giving it to loved ones who may get very sick. Getting a COVID-19 vaccine is a safer choice.

Experts are working to learn more about both natural immunity and immunity from being vaccinated. The CDC will keep the public informed as new evidence becomes available.

questionOriginal: How much does the COVID-19 vaccine cost?
questionText: How much does the COVID-19 vaccine cost?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 vaccines are free. COVID-19 vaccines are provided to Vermonters at no cost, even if you donât have health insurance. The provider that gives you your vaccine may charge an administrative fee to your insurance, but you are guaranteed a COVID-19 vaccine without paying a fee.
answerText:
COVID-19 vaccines are free. COVID-19 vaccines are provided to Vermonters at no cost, even if you donât have health insurance.
You are guaranteed a COVID-19 vaccine without paying a fee. The provider that gives you your vaccine may charge an administrative fee to your insurance. If you donât have insurance, there is a federal grant that will pay for any administrative fees.
When you make an appointment to be vaccinated, you will be asked to provide your health insurance information. Insurance is not required, and someone who doesnât have insurance will still be able to get a vaccine. But being able to bill someoneâs primary insurance does help offset some of the costs.

questionOriginal: I am not able to leave my home. How can I get the vaccine?
questionText: I am not able to leave my home. How can I get the vaccine?
answerOriginal:
We are currently working on a plan to make sure people who are unable to leave their home can get a COVID-19 vaccine. We hope to work with emergency medical services agencies across Vermont to provide in-home vaccinations to people who need it.

These in-home vaccine visits havenât started yet, and probably wonât be ready in the next phase of vaccine distribution, but we are working hard to make this possible and will put more information on our website as soon as possible.
answerText:
Homebound means you are not able to leave your home for scheduled medical or non-medical appointments. If you are currently eligible to get the vaccine and are homebound, you will be able to get the vaccine in your home.
If you are in the service of a local home health agency, the agency will reach out to you to schedule an appointment.
If you are not in the service of a home health agency, you may request an appointment by calling 802-863-7240 (toll-free 833-722-0860) Monday through Friday from 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.
Please do not make a request if you have already made one through your primary care provider, hospital, or home health agency. There is enough vaccine for everyone who is homebound. However, it will take time to reach everyone in need. In most cases, your appointment will be scheduled 10 to 14 days after you make a request.

questionOriginal: I am fully vaccinated. Do I need to quarantine if I am a close contact of someone with COVID-19?
questionText: I am fully vaccinated. Do I need to quarantine if I am a close contact of someone with COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If it has been 14 days since you got your final vaccine dose, and then you are exposed to someone with COVID-19 (for example, you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19), you do not need to quarantine only if:

  • you are within 3 months of receiving your second dose of the vaccine, and
  • you have not had any COVID-19 symptoms since the new exposure.

However, vaccinated inpatients and residents in health care settings will still need to quarantine if they are a close contact of someone with COVID-19. Read the CDCâs guidance.

This guidance does not apply to health care workers in certain situations.

However, you are not allowed to gatherÂ with people you donât live with under theÂ current social gathering guidelines.

No. You do not need to quarantine if it has been 14 days since you got your final vaccine dose, and then you are exposed to someone with COVID-19 (for example, you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19),Â and you have not had any COVID-19 symptoms since the new exposure.
However, vaccinated inpatients and residents in health care settings will still need to quarantine if they are a close contact of someone with COVID-19. Read the CDCâs guidance.

questionOriginal: What is known about variants of the COVID-19 virus?
questionText: What is known about variants of the COVID-19 virus?
answerOriginal:
Viruses constantly change through mutation, and new variants of a virus are expected to occur over time. Information about these variants is rapidly emerging. Scientists are working to learn more about how easily they spread, whether they could cause more severe illness, and whether currently authorized vaccines will protect people against them.

Multiple COVID-19 variants are circulating globally, namely in the United Kingdom (UK), South Africa and Brazil. According to the CDC, these variants seem to spread more easily and quickly than other variants, which may lead to more cases of COVID-19. You can find a map showing the number of confirmed cases caused by variants in the U.S.

The Health Department is working to detect any potential variants of concern â through genetic sequencing of certain specimens taken from various parts of the state and through wastewater testing in Burlington. We will continue this work, to help Vermonters understand any changes in the virus that may require us to strengthen our prevention efforts.

Here is what you can do to protect yourself and your community:

  • Keep up with prevention steps, like wearing masks, staying 6 feet apart, staying home if you are sick, washing your hands often, and avoiding crowded places. Prevention steps continue to be effective against variants.
  • Get tested if you think you have been exposed to COVID-19 or if you think you have any symptoms, even if they are mild. While a test is not able to determine if a variant is present, knowing that you have COVID-19 as soon as possible will help protect yourself and your community.
  • Get vaccinated when you are eligible. So far, studies suggest that the vaccines available now will help our bodies fight against strains of the virus that causes COVID-19.

Variants in Vermont

  • The B.1.1.7 variant, first identified in the UK, has now been detected in many U.S. states, including Vermont. The CDC anticipates the more easily transmissible B.1.1.7 variant will become the dominant strain in the country.
  • The B.1.429 variant, first identified in California, has been detected in Vermont.

Learn more about what we know, what we donât know, and what the CDC is doing about variants of the COVID-19 virus.

questionOriginal: What are the ingredients in the COVID-19 vaccines?
questionText: What are the ingredients in the COVID-19 vaccines?
answerOriginal:
The ingredients in the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines are similar to what is found in other vaccines â both contain the mRNA protein, fats, salts, and sugars. They do not have any fetal tissue, animal products, eggs, gelatin, latex, or preservatives in them.

Learn more about which vaccines are available in Vermont.
answerText:
The ingredients in the COVID-19 vaccines are similar to what is found in other vaccines. They contain protein, and fats, salts and polysorbate. The mRNA vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna) also have sugars and polyethylene glycol. They do not have any fetal tissue, pork products, eggs, gelatin, latex or preservatives in them.
Learn more about which vaccines are available in Vermont.

questionOriginal: Can people who recover from COVID-19 be infected again?
questionText: Can people who recover from COVID-19 be infected again?
answerOriginal: The immune response to COVID-19 is not yet understood. Patients with another type of coronavirus, MERS-CoV (also known as MERS) are unlikely to be re-infected shortly after they recover, but it is not yet known whether this is true for people sick from COVID-19.
answerText:
People who haveÂ recoveredÂ from COVID-19 can be infected again. Current data show that a person who had COVID-19 and recovered from it may have small amounts of the virusâs genetic materials in their body for at least three months after they were diagnosed with COVID-19. This means that if you have recovered from COVID-19 and are tested within three months of your initial infection, you may continue to have a positive test result.
The likelihood of a person being reinfected with COVID-19 within three months of their initial infection is low. Research regarding this is ongoing. Therefore, if you have recovered from COVID-19 and have new symptoms of COVID-19, you may need to be evaluated to see if you have COVID-19 again, especially if you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19. In this case, you should isolate and contact your health care provider to be evaluated for other causes of your symptoms, and possibly retested.

questionOriginal: Iâm afraid of or triggered by needles. How can I get the vaccine?
questionText: Iâm afraid of or triggered by needles. How can I get the vaccine?
answerOriginal:
Many people are afraid of getting vaccines because they are often given with a needle. The physical reaction inside you is very real. There are ways to overcome these fears through conditioning and practice. This can help you get the COVID-19 vaccine and other lifesaving vaccines or medical treatments you may need during your life.

Here are a few things you can do:

  • Talk to your provider about what you can expect. Knowing what is coming can help.
  • Remember to breathe. This helps calm your body and mind.
  • Distract yourself from the procedure. Fix your focus on something else like a magazine or bring a support person to help.
  • Look away from the needle.
  • Think positive thoughts. Tell yourself that you are getting a shot for protection. Tell yourself you can do it. Then the more you do it, the easier it should be next time.
answerText:
Many people are afraid of getting vaccines because they are often given with a needle. The physical reaction inside you is very real. There are ways to overcome these fears through conditioning and practice. This can help you get the COVID-19 vaccine and other lifesaving vaccines or medical treatments you may need during your life.
Here are a few things you can do:

Talk to your provider about what you can expect. Knowing what is coming can help.
Remember to breathe. This helps calm your body and mind.
Distract yourself from the procedure. Fix your focus on something else like a magazine or bring a support person to help.
Look away from the needle.
Think positive thoughts. Tell yourself that you are getting a shot for protection. Tell yourself you can do it. Then the more you do it, the easier it should be next time.

questionText: Can I get my second dose in Vermont if I got my first dose in another state?
answerOriginal: Ideally, you should schedule your second dose at the same place you got your first dose. If thatâs not possible, you can call 855-722-7878 to schedule your second dose appointment. You will need to provide a Vermont address to register.

questionOriginal: Do COVID-19 vaccines cause infertility?
questionText: Do COVID-19 vaccines cause infertility?
answerOriginal:
There is no scientific evidence that the Pfizer-BioNTech or the Moderna vaccines cause infertility, according to the Food and Drug Administration. These are mRNA vaccines, which means they are rapidly broken down in the cell. They do not go into your DNA and do not cause mutations, cellular defects or infertility, according to the American Academy of Family Physicians.

Learn more about how mRNA vaccines work.
answerText:
There is no evidence that fertility problems are a side effect of any vaccine, including COVID-19 vaccines.Â The American College of Obstetrics and GynecologyÂ recommends the vaccine for anyone who may want to get pregnant in the future.Â The vaccinesÂ do notÂ go intoÂ yourÂ DNA.
Learn more aboutÂ how mRNA vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna) work.
Learn more about how vector vaccines (Johnson & Johnson) work.

questionOriginal: Do I need to wait to get my vaccine if I am under quarantine or isolation?
questionText: Do I need to wait to get my vaccine if I am under quarantine or isolation?
answerOriginal:
Yes. You will need to postpone your appointment for the first dose or second dose until you have completed your quarantine or isolation period.

If you are under quarantine because you were exposed to someone who tested positive for COVID-19 or because you traveled, you should wait to get your vaccine until you are able to end your quarantine.

If you tested positive for COVID-19 and are still in your isolation period, you should wait to get your vaccine until you are able to end your isolation.
answerText:
If you are under quarantine, you can leave quarantine to get your first or second dose of the vaccine. However, if you have symptoms of COVID-19, contact your health care provider. You will need to stay home and reschedule your appointment.
If you tested positive for COVID-19 and are still in your isolation period, you will need to wait to get your first or second dose until you are able to end your isolation.
There are enough appointment slots available for everyone who is eligible. You will be able to easily get another appointment. Find out how to reschedule your appointment.

questionOriginal: I am an undocumented immigrant living in Vermont. Can I get the vaccine?
questionText: I am an undocumented immigrant living in Vermont. Can I get the vaccine?
answerOriginal:
Yes. You can get the vaccine when you are eligible based on age, health condition, job or setting.

When you make a vaccine appointment, you may be asked for certain information. The only answers that are needed to make a vaccine appointment are your name, date of birth, and address. This information is kept confidential since it is legally protected personal health information. If you live in Vermont but do not have an address or do not feel comfortable sharing this information, you can answer "UNKNOWN" in the street address field. You will still need to select âVTâ from the state dropdown field.

Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

Learn more about equal access to the vaccine for undocumented immigrants.

questionOriginal: How is Vermont deciding when it is safe to reopen?
questionText: How is Vermont deciding when it is safe to reopen?
answerOriginal:
Most recent modeling data suggests Vermont has reached its peak in the number of new cases of COVID-19, hospital capacity, and the number people who are currently infected with COVID-19.

However, it is important to remember that not everyone infected with the virus has symptoms and there are still many people who are currently infected and could spread it to others.

Vermont is looking at four key measures to inform steps to reopen:

  • Ongoing reduction in cases for at least 14 days
  • A health care system that is safely able to treat all patients without exceeding its capacity or using crisis standards of care
  • The ability to test all people with symptoms
  • Widespread active monitoring of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 and tracing their close contacts

At this time, Vermont continues to do well in keeping the number of cases of COVID-19 down. This is hopeful news. To continue on this path, it is critical that Vermonters continue to follow the general precautions to keep the virus from spreading and to help save lives: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.

Read the latest Vermont COVID-19 modeling projections from the Vermont Department of Financial Regulation.
answerText:
Governor Scott released a phased reopening plan â Vermont Forward -- to help Vermonters and local businesses see the path for a phased return to unrestricted travel, business operations, and event gatherings. The plan was developed by the Department of Health, the Department of Public Safety, and the Agency of Commerce and Community Development and uses vaccination milestones to ensure a safe easing of personal restrictions and continued reopening of the state's economy.
Learn about the Vermont Forward Plan.
Read the latest Vermont COVID-19 modeling projections from the Vermont Department of Financial Regulation.

questionOriginal: When do I need to get my second shot?
questionText: When do I need to get my second shot?
answerOriginal:
The COVID-19 vaccine is two shots, 21 or 28 days apart. Both of theÂ vaccines availableÂ are over 94% effective withÂ two doses. Doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine are given 21 days apart, and doses of the Moderna vaccine are given 28 days apart.

For the vaccine to be the most effective and help prevent you from getting COVID-19, you should get your second shot as close to the recommended time interval. If you miss your second dose, please get it as soon as you can.

You won't be able to make an appointment for your second dose until you get your first dose. Before you leave your first dose appointment, clinic staff will help you makeÂ an appointment to get the second dose.
answerText:
The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are two shots, given 21 or 28 days apart. Both of them are over 94% effective with two doses.

Doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine are given about 21 days apart.
Doses of the Moderna vaccine are given about 28 days apart.

For the vaccine to be the most effective and help prevent you from getting COVID-19, itâs best to get your second shot as close to the recommended schedule as possible. It is okay to get your shot 4 days before the recommended schedule. But if you miss your second dose, get it as soon as you can. However, if you are not able to get it close to the recommended schedule, it is okay to get it up to 42 days after your first dose. There is limited data on how effective the vaccine is, if the second dose is given after 42 days. Learn more about why it is important to get two doses of the vaccine.
Once you get your vaccine card, put it in a safe place so you donât lose it. You can keep it in your wallet or store it with other important documents. You can also take a picture of it with your smartphone, if you have one. You may need to show your card when you travel, so be sure to carry it with you and be prepared to show it when asked.
We recommend bringing your vaccine card to your second dose appointment, but it is not required. We also recommend getting your second dose at the same place you got your first dose. This way you can be sure that you get the same vaccine.
Find out:

How to schedule your second dose appointment
How to reschedule or cancel your second dose appointment
How to schedule a second dose appointment if you got your first dose in another state

questionOriginal: Is it possible to get COVID-19 even if Iâm fully vaccinated?
questionText: Is it possible to get COVID-19 even if Iâm fully vaccinated?
answerOriginal:
Yes. COVID-19 vaccines are very effective at preventing serious disease, including hospitalization and death. But no vaccine is 100% effective. That means some people who are vaccinated may become infected with COVID-19. This is called a âvaccine breakthrough.â This happens with any vaccine including measles, mumps, flu and others.

As more people are vaccinated, it is likely that the number of people who get sick with COVID-19 even after getting vaccinated will increase, especially if the amount of COVID-19 virus in our communities remains high. This growing number may sound concerning, but this is expected. Fortunately, the percentage of people who get COVID-19 after being vaccinated should stay low. Among those who get COVID-19 after being vaccinated, few will get very sick.

Community Immunity

Vaccine protection is more than one person being vaccinated. The more virus going around in the community, the higher your chances of coming into close contact with someone who is sick with COVID-19. When enough people in a community are protected against a contagious disease, it's very hard for it to spread. It is this community immunity that helps protect us all from getting sick. This is why â until we reach community immunity and the amount of virus in our community goes down â our prevention steps are so important.

Variants

Scientific studies show that some vaccines may not work as well on some of the variants. Studies with people in real world conditions are ongoing. Variants are circulating in Vermont and the numbers of people getting sick with COVID-19 is rising. Vermontâs numbers are too small to make any conclusions about the role of variants and the infections among fully vaccinated people that we are seeing. The Health Department is working to increase our ability to sequence more samples and select certain samples, like those among fully vaccinated people to look at more closely.

Learn more from the CDC about:

  • What you should know about the possibility of COVID-19 illness after vaccination
  • Vaccine breakthrough cases

questionOriginal: What do college students need to know?
questionText: What do college students need to know?
answerOriginal:
Colleges and universities must follow the Mandatory Guidance for College and University Campus Learning. Please contact your college or university directly for information about arriving on campus, testing and health guidance.

We don't yet know if out-of-state college students will be able to get vaccinated in Vermont. Conversations are ongoing, and we will share information as soon as we have it.

If you are coming home to Vermont for a break or holiday,Â you must quarantine for 14 days once you arrive. You can end quarantine early if you get tested on or after day 7 of your quarantine and get a negative test result. You must not have had any symptoms of COVID-19, and must continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days. Find out more aboutÂ theÂ optionÂ to end your quarantine early.

There is a Supportive Quarantine Pilot Program for students and others moving to Burlington and for people asked to quarantine as part of contact tracing. The program includes a daily check-in, move-in care package and gift certificate.

Parents or other visitors can find information on traveling to Vermont and quarantine, information on how to drop off someone at college, and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.

Find out what happens at the Health Department when someone tests positive for COVID-19.

Find tips for how to enjoy safer sex and reduce the risk of spreading COVID-19 and more resources for college students.
answerText:
Vaccination
All college students can get vaccinated now. Make a vaccine appointment.
Getting Tested Due to Travel
If you are a college student coming home to Vermont and are not vaccinated, you must get tested within 3 days of returning to Vermont. Day 0 is the day you arrive back in Vermont. Find free and fast testing throughout Vermont.
If you are an out-of-state college student coming to Vermont and are not vaccinated, you must get tested within 3 days before arriving in Vermont.
In both cases above, the test must be for a current infection (like a PCR test), except it cannot be an antigen test (also known as a rapid test).
Parents or other visitors who are not vaccinated will need to get tested within 3 days before arriving in Vermont. Learn more about the travel rules for visitors to Vermont. Find answers to frequently asked questions about travel.
If you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 within the last 3 months (and donât have new symptoms), you do not need to get tested.
General Guidance and Other Resources
Colleges and universities must follow the Mandatory Guidance for College and University Campus Learning. Please contact your college or university directly for information about arriving on campus, testing and health guidance.
Find out what happens at the Health Department when someone tests positive for COVID-19.
Find tips for how to enjoy safer sex and reduce the risk of spreading COVID-19 and more resources for college students.

questionOriginal: How can I report a business or person who is not complying with the Governor's executive orders?
questionText: How can I report a business or person who is not complying with the Governor's executive orders?
answerOriginal:
Enforcement of the Governorâs executive orders is mainly done through education and voluntary compliance.

  • For concerns about businesses, lodging establishments, short-term rental properties, nonprofits or other entities that are not complying with the Governorâs orders, call your local law enforcement agency, or file a report by contacting the Vermont Department of Health at 802-863-7240 (toll-free 833-722-0860) or AHS.VDHPublicCommunication@vermont.gov.
  • For concerns or complaints about restaurants, use the Health Departmentâs online sanitation complaint form, email FoodLodging@vermont.gov, or call 802-863-7221.
  • For employees to report alleged safety or health hazards, use the Vermont Occupational Safety and Health Administrationâs (VOSHA) confidential online safety complaint form.
  • For complaints about people who are not quarantining as required, call your local law enforcement agency. Do not dial 911. Only use their non-emergency number when calling in a report.

Learn more about how the executive orders are enforced.

For concerns or complaints about restaurants, use the Health Departmentâs online sanitation complaint form, email FoodLodging@vermont.gov, or call 802-863-7221.

questionOriginal: Why was the Johnson & Johnson vaccine paused?
questionText: Why was the Johnson & Johnson vaccine paused?
answerOriginal:
Vermont has resumed use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine as of April 26. The FDA and CDC announced that they studied and confirmed that the Johnson & Johnson vaccine is recommended for people 18 years of age and older, and that the pause on its use since April 13 can be lifted.

The CDC announced the pause after reports of a small number of people developing a rare and severe type of blood clot called cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST). This type of blood clot is found in the blood vessels that drain blood from the brain and is combined with low platelets.

There have been no reported cases of these side effects in Vermont.

The pause was necessary to give the CDCâs Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices time to review additional data about the reported side effects.

Vermontâs health care providers have been given information and guidance about the potential blood clotting symptoms and appropriate medical treatment. They will be given any updated guidance.

Although the side effects of concern are extremely rare, the FDA and CDC recommend that you should contact your health care provider right away if you develop severe headache, abdominal pain, leg pain or shortness of breath within three weeks of receiving the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.

To register for an appointment or to change the one you already have, go online or call 855-722-7878. Certain participating pharmacy partners, including CVS and Walgreens, are making plans to also offer the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. You can contact those pharmacies directly to make an appointment or to reschedule.

The CDC announced the pause after reports of a small number of people developing a rare and severe type of blood clot called cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST). This type of blood clot is found in the blood vessels that drain blood from the brain and is combined with low platelets.
There have been no reported cases of these side effects in Vermont.
The pause was necessary to give the CDCâs Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices time to review additional data about the reported side effects.

You can contact those pharmacies directly to make an appointment or to reschedule.

questionOriginal: What do parents need to know about school and child care?
questionText: What do parents need to know about school and child care?
answerOriginal:
Children need structure, relationships with their peers, teachers, and other adults for their academic, social, and emotional development. Although remote learning is an important tool during the pandemic, it can lead to even greater gaps in equity. Public health and education experts considered all these factors when writing Vermontâs guidance to open schools, which focuses on the safety of teachers, staff, and students.

Vermont has seen cases and outbreaks in schools and child care, but by following health guidance, we are all working together to keep the virus out of schools as much as possible and prevent it from spreading through physical distancing, wearing masks, hand hygiene, and contact tracing.

Helpful resources for parents:

  • What parents can expect for pre-K through 12th grade
  • Safety and health guidance for Vermont schools from the Agency of Education
  • School-based sports program guidance from the Agency of Education
  • Music education guidance from the Agency of Education
  • Child care and out-of-school-time care guidance
  • Overnight summer camp operations guidance
  • Returning to school following illness
  • Returning to child care or an out of school care program following illness
  • What if there is a case of COVID-19 in school?
  • COVID-19 cases in K-12 learning communities while infectious
  • Strategies and resources for educators and families from the Agency of Education
  • Vermont PBS distance learning
  • More information for families with children

questionOriginal: Who will be eligible next?
questionText: Who will be eligible next?
answerOriginal:
In addition to ongoing vaccination of health care workers and residents and staff of long-term care facilities, Vermont is usingÂ age groupingsÂ to determine who can receive the vaccine next based on our primary goal with vaccination efforts â to save lives.

Currently, only those age 75 and older are eligible to receive the vaccine. There are no exceptions based on age, chronic condition, circumstances of employment, or any other factor. In the weeks and months to come, age-based criteria will expand to include those age 70 and older, followed by those age 65 and older. When that population has been vaccinated, Vermonters with specific chronic conditions will be included.

After the age groups, the vaccine will be available to people in Vermont who have certain high-risk health conditions. These are medical conditions that put them at increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19 as identified by the CDC. These are:

  • Current cancer
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • COPD, also called emphysema
  • Heart conditions, such as heart failure, coronary artery disease, or cardiomyopathies
  • Immunocompromised state (weakened immune system)
  • Severe obesity
  • Pregnancy
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Down Syndrome
  • Sickle cell disease

Stay tuned to our website for updates on the next phases.
answerText:
All Vermont residents age 16 and older are eligible to be vaccinated. Some residents of another state are also eligible.
Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.
You can also find specific clinic locations for certain groups:

People who are homebound
Clinic options for Black, Indigenous and people of color (BIPOC)
Clinic options for English language learners and people in immigrant/refugee communities

Learn about how we are working toward equity.
The goal is to have Vermonters fully vaccinated by July. The length of the entire process will vary, but you can expect it to take about 2 months from when you sign up to when you are considered fully vaccinated. This includes the time between when you make your appointment, the time of getting your first and final dose, and the 14 days after your final dose for the vaccine to be most effective.

questionOriginal: If I have symptoms after getting the vaccine, can I go to work if I donât pass the health screening?
questionText: If I have symptoms after getting the vaccine, can I go to work if I donât pass the health screening?
answerOriginal: No. There are some signs and symptoms that could be related to getting the COVID-19 vaccine or being infected with the COVID-19 virus or another virus (like the flu). These include fever, chills, fatigue and muscle aches. If you have these symptoms, whether you got the COVID-19 vaccine or not, you should not go to work and you should call your health care provider. If your health care provider determines that your symptoms are associated with the COVID-19 vaccine, then you can return to work if you feel well enough to do so.

questionOriginal: How can someone make a vaccine appointment if they donât have internet access or don't know how to use a computer?
questionText: How can someone make a vaccine appointment if they donât have internet access or don't know how to use a computer?
answerOriginal:
Registering online will be the quickest way to make an appointment. If your loved one or someone you care for is 75 years or older, we ask that you help them register online. Find out how to make an appointment for someone else.

If registering online is not an option, you can call 855-722-7878 Monday through Friday from 8:15 a.m. â 5:30 p.m. and Saturday to Sunday 10:00 a.m. â 3:00 p.m.

questionOriginal: How do I reschedule or cancel my vaccine appointment?
questionText: How do I reschedule or cancel my vaccine appointment?
answerOriginal:
It is very important that you keep the appointment you made. Please do not make an appointment if you are not sure you will be able to keep it. Cancellations and unplanned no-shows could cause the vaccine to be spoiled.

If you need to cancel your appointment, please do as soon as possible. You will need to log in to your account and cancel it there.

If you need to reschedule your appointment, call 855-722-7878. If you reschedule it online,Â youâll have to cancel your current appointment and may risk not getting an earlier one.
answerText:
It is very important that you keep the appointment you made. Please do not make an appointment if you are not sure you will be able to keep it, especially your second dose appointment. Cancellations and unplanned no-shows could cause the vaccine to be spoiled.
The best way to make sure you get your second dose as soon as possible is to keep the appointment you have scheduled. If you miss your appointment or have to reschedule because of an injury or illness, you can log in to your account to find a new appointment.
Appointments will likely be limited, and you may have to travel up to 1.5 hours away to find a new second dose appointment. You may also need to wait up to six weeks between your first and second dose appointments. For these reasons, we strongly encourage people to keep their scheduled second dose appointment.
For appointments made through the Health Department website:

If you need to cancel your appointment, please do as soon as possible. You will need to log in to your account and click on the âCancelâ button.
If you need to reschedule your appointment, log in to your account and click on the âRescheduleâ button. You can then search for and choose another appointment. Your original appointment will not be canceled if you do not find a better date, time or location.
If you need help or are not able to cancel or reschedule your appointment online, call 855-722-7878.

For appointments made through a pharmacyâs appointment website, contact the pharmacy if you would like to reschedule or cancel any of your appointments.

questionOriginal: How do I make my second dose appointment?
questionText: How do I make my second dose appointment?
answerOriginal:
If you make your appointment through the Health Department website and are getting a vaccine that requires two doses, clinic staff will schedule your dose 2 appointment before you leave your dose 1 appointment. You can also schedule your own dose 2 appointment online or by calling 855-722-7878, but only after you go to your dose 1 appointment.

If you make your appointment with a pharmacy partner that has their own appointment website, they may do things a bit differently:

  • Kinney Drugs schedules second dose appointments at the first dose appointment.
  • CVS allows you to schedule first and second doses at the same time. Or you can schedule only dose 2. Your dose 1 doesnât have to be from CVS. You will need to select which vaccine you got for dose 1 to make sure you get the same vaccine type for dose 2.
  • Walgreens allows you to schedule dose 1 and dose 2 at the same time, but only if dose 2 appointments are available. Otherwise, neither dose appointments can be scheduled. Or you can just schedule dose 2 and you will need to select which vaccine you got for dose 1 to make sure you get the same vaccine type for dose 2.

Find out how to reschedule your appointment.

CVS allows you to schedule first and second doses at the same time. Or you can schedule only dose 2. Your dose 1 doesnât have to be from CVS. You will need to select which vaccine you got for dose 1 to make sure you get the same vaccine type for dose 2.
Walgreens allows you to schedule dose 1 and dose 2 at the same time, but only if dose 2 appointments are available. Otherwise, neither dose appointments can be scheduled. Or you can just schedule dose 2 and you will need to select which vaccine you got for dose 1 to make sure you get the same vaccine type for dose 2.

Find out how to reschedule your appointment.

questionOriginal: What is quarantine?
questionText: What is quarantine?
answerOriginal:
Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from others. It is for people with no symptoms who are returning to Vermont from certain out-of-state locations or people who were in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19. Quarantine helps prevent the spread of COVID-19 before a person knows they are sick, or if they are infected with the virus and donât have symptoms. Learn more about the timeline for close contacts, from when they have may have been exposed to when they can end quarantine.

Quarantine means staying at a home or dwelling for 14 days since the day they were potentially exposed to COVID-19 before doing any activities outside of the home, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. People in quarantine should separate themselves from others and check themselves for symptoms.

We strongly encourage anyone in quarantine to sign up forÂ daily symptom check reminders.

Check the latest quarantine guidance for people visiting or returning to Vermont and find answers to travel-related quarantine questions.

Learn more:

  • What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation
  • What to do if you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19
  • Tips about quarantining when you share a home
answerText:
Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from other people. This helps to prevent the spread of COVID-19 before a person knows they are sick, or if they are infected with the virus and donât have symptoms.
Quarantine is for people who were in close contact with someone with COVID-19 (unless you are fully vaccinated or recently had COVID-19). Day 1 of your quarantine starts the day after you were last in contact with them.
Quarantine means you need to stay home and away from other people for 14 days. This means you canât do any activities outside of your home, like going to school, work, or out to do errands. You should separate yourself from others and check yourself for symptoms. Call your health care provider if you start to feel sick. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
You are allowed to go outside for a walk or a bike ride while you are in quarantine only if:

you do not have any symptoms,
you are alone,
you wear a mask at all times,
you are in an uncrowded place, and
you can stay at least 6 feet from other people at all times.

For example, you can go for a walk or bike ride in your neighborhood. You should not go for a walk or bike ride on a bike path, on busy hiking or biking trails, or in a downtown area.
You can end quarantine early if you get tested on or after day 7 of your quarantine and get a negative test result. You must not have had any symptoms of COVID-19, and must continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days. Find out more about the option to end your quarantine early.
Find out if you need to quarantine if:

You are a close contact of someone with COVID-19.
You had close contact with someone who is under quarantine.
You live with or had close contact with someone who tested positive.
You live with someone who is waiting for their test results.
You take care of someone who is in isolation and canât avoid close contact with them.
You take care of someone who is in quarantine and canât avoid close contact with them.

Learn more:

What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation?
What to do if you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19
Timeline for close contacts of people with COVID-19
Tips about quarantining when you share a home

questionOriginal: Do I have a choice of which vaccine I get? Which vaccine should I get?
questionText: Do I have a choice of which vaccine I get? Which vaccine should I get?
answerOriginal:
If you are making an appointment through the Health Department system, you will see the name of the vaccine listed after the âeventâ description. However, there is no way to search for an appointment based on which vaccine is available. Currently, most clinics are offering the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines (two-dose), and some are offering the Johnson & Johnson (single dose) vaccine. Learn about why the Johnson & Johnson vaccine was briefly paused.

Please note that only sites with the Pfizer vaccine will show up for people age 16 and 17 since that is the only vaccine that has been authorized for people age 16 and older. You may need to look at neighboring counties if nothing comes up in your county.

For the two-dose vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna), you should get the same vaccine for both your first and second dose. You will also be given a card with the name of the vaccine you received when you get your first shot. If you have a smartphone, you may want to take a picture of the card in case you misplace it.

Find out how to make your second dose appointment.

All three vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna and Johnson & Johnson) are safe and similarly effective at preventing severe illness and death. This standard is what is most commonly used to assess other vaccines like the flu shot. We cannot directly compare the effectiveness of the three vaccines because they were not studied against each other at the same time. Each clinical trial had different study protocols, timing and location. For example, variants werenât widely circulating when the earlier vaccines were being tested.

The vaccines available have similar side effects. Side effects are a normal way that your body builds immunity to COVID-19.

Learn more about the vaccines available in Vermont.

questionOriginal: Is there a standby list for extra or leftover vaccine doses? Will the Health Department call me?
questionText: Is there a standby list for extra or leftover vaccine doses? Will the Health Department call me?
answerOriginal:
Please do not show up at state-run vaccine clinics to wait for extra doses. These clinics include those run by the Health Department, the National Guard, health care partners, Costco, Hannaford, Price Chopper, Rite Aid, Shaws and Walmart. Clinics cannot accept walk-ins. You need to have an appointment to get a vaccine. However, from time to time, some clinics will be able to accept walk-ins. When that happens, we will share that information on our website and on social media.

To help make sure we do not waste vaccine doses, state-run clinics make an estimate of how many doses may remain at the end of the day. If there is a possibility that there will be extra doses, then clinic staff will estimate how many may be available and call people who are currently scheduled for a future COVID-19 vaccine appointment to come in. We canât guarantee that you will get the vaccine earlier if you are called because the estimated number of available doses could change.

The Health Department will reach out to you if there is a certain clinic that needs people for a standby list. Please do not call the Health Department to be put on the standby list. If you made an appointment through the state registration system that is three weeks or more away, you may get a call to ask if you are interested in being on the standby list. The call may come from a Vermont number or may appear to come from another state. You will only need to answer âyesâ or âno.â You will not be asked for your contact information or any other personal information since you are already in our system.

You will not lose your scheduled vaccination appointment if you join the standby list. But please do not cancel your original appointment since we cannot guarantee you a vaccine even if you are called. If you do get your vaccine earlier, then the clinic staff will cancel your original appointment.

If you are called, you would need to be able to arrive 30 minutes before the end of the clinic. Youâll be told what that time is when you are called. Clinics happen both weekdays and some weekends and are held during the day and sometimes in the evening.

questionOriginal: I am hosting out-of-state visitors in my home. Do I need to quarantine?
questionText: I am hosting out-of-state visitors in my home. Do I need to quarantine?
answerOriginal:
Under the current gathering guidelines, visitors from one household are allowed to stay in your home only if they are all fully vaccinated or if everyone in your household is fully vaccinated. Learn more about Vermontâs gathering restrictions and exceptions.

Under the current travel guidelines, visitors to Vermont must quarantine if they are not fully vaccinated. Children who travel with their fully vaccinated parent or caregiver must quarantine. Learn more about Vermontâs travel quarantine requirements.

This means that you may host visitors who are under quarantine only if your household is fully vaccinated. Since children cannot get vaccinated at this time, a household with children is not considered a fully vaccinated household.

If you are hosting visitors who are under quarantine in your home or lodging, you do not also need to quarantine. That means you can go to school, work, or the grocery store. However, you need to stay at least 6 feet from the people who are under quarantine. People who are under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with the people who are hosting them. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.

Find more travel and quarantine information and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.
answerText:
Yes, but there are some restrictions. Under the current gathering guidelines, hosting visitors is considered a social gathering. Both you and your guests must follow Vermontâs gathering restrictions.
Find moreÂ travel informationÂ and answers toÂ frequently asked questions about travel.

questionOriginal: I am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?
questionText: I am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?
answerOriginal:
Anyone currently under quarantine who is not a health care worker or a correctional worker, and who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required.

This includes:

  • people returning to Vermont (for example, those who spend winter outside of Vermont, second homeowners and college students)

  • visitors coming into Vermont

  • close contacts of people who have tested positive

For anyone coming into Vermont, Day 0 is the day you arrive in Vermont.

Health care workers and correctional workers must complete the full 14-day quarantine.

You can end your quarantine period only if:

  • You have not had symptoms during your quarantine period.

  • You are tested on Day 7 or later.

  • You remain in quarantine until the result comes back.

  • You receive a negative test result and are still not having symptoms.

However, you must continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days and isolate at home immediately if symptoms develop.
answerText:
If you are currently under quarantine and have had no symptoms of COVID-19 during the first seven days of quarantine, you have the option to be tested and end your quarantine early. The test must be for a current infection (like a PCR test), except it cannot be an antigen test (also known as a rapid test).
You can end your quarantine period before 14 days only if:

You have not had symptoms during your quarantine period;
You are tested on day 7 or later;
You remain in quarantine until the result comes back;
You receive a negative test result and are still not having symptoms; and
You continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days.

If you develop symptoms at any point during your quarantine, contact your health care provider and the Health Department right away.
There are a variety of testing options available to you: your health care provider, pharmacies and Health Department testing sites. Find out where to get tested.
If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
Studies have found most people will develop symptoms by day 7. This is why there is the option for people to be tested on day 7 or after in their quarantine and, if the test is negative, to end quarantine.
Residents and staff of group living facilities (for example long-term care facilities or corrections facilities) and new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine.

questionOriginal: What are the current requirements for businesses, organizations and workplaces?
questionText: What are the current requirements for businesses, organizations and workplaces?
answerOriginal:
As part of Vermont's phased reopening plan, most sectors have transitioned to universal guidance and some will need to also follow specialized guidance.

More resources:

  • Health guidance and resources for businesses
  • What to do if an employee tests positive for COVID-19
  • What to do if a guest or visitor at your establishment tests positive for COVID-19
  • What to do if you operate a critical infrastructure business and your essential workers are close contacts

  • COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses
  • COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses from the ACCD
  • Best Practices for Retail Food Stores, Restaurants, and Food Pick-Up/Delivery Services During the COVID-19 Pandemic from the Food and Drug Administration

The Health Department and Agency of Agriculture do not recommend the use of fogging, fumigation, âelectrostatic or wide-area spraying on hard surfaces to control the spread of COVID-19. These methods, while they can be effective, âare unnecessary and do not clean contaminated surfaces. They also may result in chemical exposures to workers and the public. Additionally, the Environmental Protection Agency does not recommend using these methods to apply disinfectants unless the label specifically states it is appropriate to do so.

questionOriginal: Are there any travel rules for people visiting Vermont or for Vermonters returning to Vermont (including travel for essential purposes and day trips)?
questionText: Are there any travel rules for people visiting Vermont or for Vermonters returning to Vermont (including travel for essential purposes and day trips)?
answerOriginal:
No. As part of Vermont's phased reopening plan, travel no longer requires testing or quarantine. Rules for visitors from other countries and Vermonters returning from international travel are different. Learn more about international travel.

The CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19.

The CDC requires everyone toÂ wear masks when usingÂ publicÂ transportation.

If you are fully vaccinated, be sure to carry your COVID-19 vaccine card with you and be prepared to show it when asked.

If you are a health care worker, check with your employer about any additional requirements.

Check Vermontâs current mask requirements and limitsÂ on gatherings and events.

questionOriginal: What do I need to know about COVID-19 testing? Where can I get tested?
questionText: What do I need to know about COVID-19 testing? Where can I get tested?
answerOriginal:
You can get tested at a Health Department testing site if you live or work in Vermont and do not have symptoms. This includes children 12 months or older. Anyone under 18 should be accompanied by a parent or guardian or bring a signed parental consent form.

There are a variety of testing options available to you: your health care provider, pharmacies and Health Department testing sites. Find out where to get tested and how to schedule an appointment.

If you have symptoms of COVID-19, do not go to a testing site. Talk to your health care provider. If you don't have a provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics.

The Health Department recommends testing as soon as possible when:

  • you have symptoms of COVID-19 (call your health care provider first).
  • you are referred by your health care provider.
  • a person in your workplace or household, or a person you attended an event with, tests positive for COVID-19.
  • you plan on going to a social gathering with people you don't live with (other than recreating with one masked person outside). You should get tested before the gathering, right after, and again on day 7.

If you often gather socially with people you don't live with, you should get tested weekly.

College students returning to Vermont from out of state should quarantine and be tested on or after day 7 of quarantine after returning home.

Travelers to Vermont and Vermonters returning from out of state must follow quarantine requirements. You have the option to get a PCR test on or after day 7 of quarantine and end your quarantine early with a negative test result.

There is no cost to individuals for a PCR test for COVID-19, even if you donât have health insurance.

You may come to a Health Department testing site to get tested more than once if you have reason to be concerned about infection.

Health Department testing sites use nasal swabs. This is a self-administered test, which means that you use a short, dry swab to collect a sample from the front of your nose.

If you need a ride to the testing site, schedule your appointment first, and then call 833-387-7200 at least two days before the appointment.

Find out:

  • Where to get tested and how to schedule an appointment
  • What to expect at a Health Department testing site â including answers to more questions about testing
  • What to do while youâre waiting for test results and how to get your test results
  • When you will get your test results
  • What the different types of tests are
  • How many Vermonters have been tested â this information is updated daily.
answerText:
There are a variety of testing options available to you: your health care provider, pharmacies and Health Department testing sites. You can make an appointment or just walk in. Testing is free to all, and many sites now let you take your own sample using a short swab in your nose.
Find out where to get tested.
Anyone can get tested at a Health Department testing site if they do not have symptoms. This includes children 12 months or older, people who work in Vermont, visitors to Vermont and international travelers. Infants under 12 months can get tested at their health care providerâs office. Anyone under 18 should be accompanied by a parent or guardian or bring a signed parental consent form.
The Health Department uses and recommends PCR tests. You can get other tests, like at-home or saliva tests. However, if you are testing out of quarantine early, the test must be for a current infection (like a PCR test), except it cannot be an antigen test (also known as a rapid test).
If you have symptoms of COVID-19, do not go to a testing site. Talk to your health care provider about getting tested.
If you or your child don't have a provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics. If you are visiting Vermont or are an international traveler, you will need to contact your primary care provider or call Vermont 2-1-1 if you do not have a provider.
The Health Department recommends testing as soon as possible when:

You have symptoms of COVID-19 (call your health care provider first).
You are referred by your health care provider.
You are not fully vaccinated and a person in your workplace or household, or a person you attended an event with, tests positive for COVID-19.

You may come to a Health Department testing site to get tested more than once if you have reason to be concerned about infection.
If you need a ride to the testing site, schedule your appointment first, and then call 833-387-7200 at least two days before the appointment.
Find out:

Where to get tested and how to schedule an appointment
What to expect at a Health Department testing site â including answers to more questions about testing
What to do while youâre waiting for test results
When you will get your test results
What the different types of tests are
How many Vermonters have been tested â this information is updated daily.

questionOriginal: Should I get a COVID-19 vaccine with other vaccines?
questionText: Should I get a COVID-19 vaccine with other vaccines?
answerOriginal: The COVID-19 vaccine should be given alone. Wait at least 14 days between the COVID-19 vaccine and other vaccines, including the shingles vaccine.
answerText: You can get a COVID-19 vaccine and other vaccines at the same time. You no longer need to wait 14 days between getting the COVID-19 vaccine and other vaccines.

questionOriginal: How long does it take for the vaccine to protect me from getting COVID-19?
questionText: How long does it take for the vaccine to protect me from getting COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
You may not be protected from COVID-19 until you are fully vaccinated, which is 14 days after your final shot. It takes time for the vaccine to train your body to fight COVID-19.

The vaccine protects you from serious illness, but we donât know for sure if you can give the virus to someone else. Some recent studies suggest that a person who is vaccinated is less likely to infect other people with the COVID-19 virus. Until enough people are vaccinated and we know more, it is important to continue following the prevention steps, like wearing a mask, keeping 6 feet apart, and washing your hands, and to follow the social gathering guidelines, even after youâve been vaccinated.
answerText:
You may not be protected from COVID-19 until you are fully vaccinated, which is 14 days after your final shot. It takes time for the vaccine to train your body to fight COVID-19.
The vaccine protects you from serious illness, and may also protect the people around you. Until we learn more, it is important to continue following the prevention steps, like wearing a mask, keeping 6 feet apart, and washing your hands, even after you are fully vaccinated.

questionOriginal: I am pregnant or breastfeeding. Should I get vaccinated?
questionText: I am pregnant or breastfeeding. Should I get vaccinated?
answerOriginal:
Based on how mRNA vaccines work, experts believe they are unlikely to pose a specific risk for people who are pregnant. However, the actual risks of mRNA vaccines to the pregnant person and their fetus are unknown because these vaccines have not been studied in pregnant people. Pregnant people have a slightly higher risk for poor outcomes, as do their fetuses, with COVID-19 infection. Studies are on-going.

If you are pregnant and part of a group that is recommended to receive the vaccine (for example, health care personnel), you may choose to be vaccinated. The CDC and other professional organizations recommend that you consult with your health care provider.

There are no data on the safety of COVID-19 vaccines in people who are breastfeeding or the effects of mRNA vaccines on milk production/excretion or on the breastfed baby. mRNA vaccines are not thought to be a risk to the breastfed baby. A person who is breastfeeding and is part of a group recommended to receive a COVID-19 vaccine (for example, health care personnel) may choose to be vaccinated.
answerText:
Yes. If you are pregnant or breastfeeding, you can get a COVID-19 vaccine. You might want to talk with your health care provider to help you decide whether to get vaccinated. While this conversation might be helpful, it is not required before you get your vaccine.
Based on how these vaccines work in the body (that is, they do not reproduce inside your bodyâs cells), experts believe they are unlikely to pose a risk for people who are pregnant, people who are lactating or breastfeeding babies. However, there are currently limited data on the safety of COVID-19 vaccines in pregnant people. Additionally, there are no data on the safety of COVID-19 vaccines in people who are breastfeeding, the effects of the vaccines on milk production or excretion, or the effects of vaccination on the breastfed baby.
For more information, watch the video Sara Asks about the COVID-19 Vaccine, which is also available in other languages. Learn more from the CDC about vaccination considerations for people who are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Pregnant people with COVID-19 are at an increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19 â including hospitalization, intensive care, a ventilator or special equipment to help them breathe, and death â compared with non-pregnant people. Additionally, pregnant people with COVID-19 might be at increased risk of other adverse outcomes, such as preterm birth (delivering the baby earlier than 37 weeks). Learn more from the CDC about COVID-19 and pregnancy.
We donât know for sure if people with COVID-19 can spread the virus to babies through their breast milk, but the current evidence suggests that it is not likely. Learn more from the CDC about COVID-19 and breastfeeding.

questionOriginal: How can I get a copy of my vaccine record? Can I get a new vaccine card if I lose it?
questionText: How can I get a copy of my vaccine record? Can I get a new vaccine card if I lose it?
answerOriginal:
Once you get your vaccine card, put it in a safe place so you donât lose it. You can keep it in your wallet or store it with other important documents. You can also take a picture of it with your smartphone, if you have one. You may need to show your card when you travel, so be sure to carry it with you and be prepared to show it when asked.

If your vaccine requires a second dose, you should have scheduled your second dose at the clinic where you received your first dose. We recommend bringing your vaccine card to your second dose appointment, but it is not required.

You may want to protect your card. If you choose to get your vaccine card laminated, please note that the ink used to write in your dose could run when heat is applied. Also, if booster shots are needed, they wonât be able to be recorded if the card is laminated.

If you lost your vaccine card or your information is wrong, the Vermont Immunization Registry has your vaccination record. You can request a record of your vaccine from the Immunization Registry directly or through your health care provider. To request it directly through the Immunization Registry, email vaxrecordrequest@vermont.gov or call 888-688-4667, option 3. You can get a copy of your record as an encrypted email or through the mail. On weekdays, you can expect an email within an hour or two. Mail will take about one week.
