questionOriginal: Can I still infect someone with the COVID-19 virus after I've been fully vaccinated?
questionText: Can I still infect someone with the COVID-19 virus after I've been fully vaccinated?
answerOriginal:
You may not be protected from COVID-19 until you are fully vaccinated, which is 14 days after your final shot. While the vaccine protects you from serious illness, we donât know yet if you can give the virus to someone else.

However, some recent studies suggest that a person who is vaccinated is less likely to infect other people with the COVID-19 virus. Until more research is done, it is important that you continue to follow the prevention steps, like wearing a mask, keeping 6 feet apart, and washing your hands, and to follow the social gathering guidelines, even after youâve been vaccinated.

Learn more about the studies:

  • Decreased SARS-CoV-2 viral load following vaccination
  • Transmission of COVID-19 in 282 clusters in Catalonia, Spain: a cohort study
answerText:
If youâre fully vaccinated, you are less likely to spread the virus. A growing body of evidence suggests that fully vaccinated people are less likely to have COVID-19 without symptoms and to spread COVID-19 to others.
The vaccines are working in the real world. Studies show them to be more than 90% effective in real-world settings in preventing mild and severe disease, hospitalization and death. The vaccines have also proven to be effective against the COVID-19 variants that are currently circulating in the country.

questionOriginal: I am a parent. What do I need to know, and how can I help keep my children safe from COVID-19?
questionText: I am a parent. What do I need to know, and how can I help keep my children safe from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
There are gathering restrictions in Vermont. You are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with. But if you are fully vaccinated, you can gather with one other household at a time. Learn more about Vermontâs gathering restrictions and exceptions.

If you do gather with people you donât live with, you should quarantine. Quarantine means staying home and away from other people for 14 days. The Health Department strongly encourages you to get tested before the gathering, as soon as 2 days after the gathering, and again 7 days after the gathering. If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.

If you are around other people, itâs safest to be outdoors. Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading or getting COVID-19.

Gathering in groups or âpodsâ related to education or child care that are already formed can continue. Gathering in pods related to social activity, informal playgroups, playdates, or sleepovers are not allowed at this time. New pods of any kind are discouraged.

For outdoor recreation with people you donât live with, keep a physical distance of at least 6 feet and wear a mask. There are no other limitations to outdoor activities. Being active outside is good for our mental and physical health!

Follow these general prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

  • Stay home if you are sick.
  • Wash your hands often.
  • Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
  • Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
  • Wear a mask (children over 2 who are able) anytime you are around people you donât live with.

There will always be some risk of COVID-19 when we leave home, but it is possible to live your life and stay safer. Look for three things to help weigh the risk when making plans or going out:

  • 6-Foot Spaces: Can I easily keep 6 feet from others?
  • Masks on Faces: Will people wear masks?
  • Uncrowded Places: Is there enough space for people to spread out?

Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.

Children can also continue to take advantage of technology to play games or keep in touch with friends and family. These changes will continue to be difficult, but we are all doing our part to slow down this pandemic.

Learn more:

  • Resources for families with children
  • Coping with family stress during COVID-19
  • Face coverings for children
  • Frequently asked questions about school and child care
answerText:
Vaccination
Since children under age 12 cannot get vaccinated at this time, they are considered unvaccinated.
Vermont is now vaccinating 12- to 15-year-olds, following the approval of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine for emergency use in this age group. Learn more about vaccinating 12- to 15-year-olds.
Learn more about why younger children canât get vaccinated yet, and how to make an appointment for 12 to 17-year-olds.
Testing
Children 12 months or older can get tested at a Health Department testing site if they do not have symptoms. Infants under 12 months can get tested at their health care providerâs office. Anyone under 18 should be accompanied by a parent or guardian or bring a signed parental consent form. Learn more about getting tested for COVID-19.
If your child has symptoms of COVID-19, do not go to a testing site. Talk to their health care provider about getting tested. If your child doesn't have a provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics.
Social Gatherings
Find out the current limits on gatherings and events.
When gathering with other households, itâs safest to be outdoors. Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading or getting COVID-19.
When you are outdoors, masks are only required when you are in a crowd or with multiple other households where you canât maintain a 6-foot distance, whether you are vaccinated or not.
Parental Shared Custody
We encourage you to choose the form of travel with the lowest risk when you can, which is your personal vehicle. The CDC requires everyone to wear masks when using public transportation.
Children in shared custody that are in isolation because they have tested positive for COVD-19, or are in quarantine because they were identified as a close contact of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19, may isolate or quarantine in either household. It does not affect the shared custody schedule. However, this means that members of the household where the child is staying may need to quarantine. If the child is in isolation, household members will be required to quarantine. If the child is in quarantine, household members would not need to also quarantine, unless the child tests positive for COVID-19.
Prevention
There will always be some risk of COVID-19 when we leave home, but it is possible to live your life and stay safer. Look for three things to help weigh the risk when making plans or going out:

6-Foot Spaces: Can I easily keep 6 feet from others?
Masks on Faces: Will people wear masks?
Uncrowded Places: Is there enough space for people to spread out?

Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.
Learn more:

Resources for families with children
Coping with family stress during COVID-19
Frequently asked questions about school and child care

questionOriginal: What are the long-term health effects of COVID-19?
questionText: What are the long-term health effects of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
The CDC is working to learn more about the whole range of short- and long-term health effects associated with COVID-19. Many organs besides the lungs are affected by COVID-19, and there are many ways the infection can affect someoneâs health.

One of the health effects that the CDC is closely watching and working to understand relates to COVID-19 and the heart. Heart conditions associated with COVID-19 include inflammation and damage to the heart muscle itself, known as myocarditis, or inflammation of the covering of the heart, known as pericarditis. These conditions can occur by themselves or in combination. Heart damage may be an important part of severe disease and death from COVID-19, especially in older people with underlying illnesses. Heart damage like this might also explain some frequently reported long-term symptoms like shortness of breath, chest pain, and heart palpitations.

The risk of heart damage may not be limited to older and middle-aged adults. For example, young adults with COVID-19, including athletes, can also suffer from myocarditis. Severe heart damage has occurred in young, healthy people, but is rare. There may be more cases of mild effects of COVID-19 on the heart that can be diagnosed with special imaging tests, including in younger people with mild or minimal symptoms; however, the long-term significance of these mild effects on the heart are unknown. The CDC will continue to assess and provide updates as new data emerge.
answerText:
Although most people with COVID-19 get better within weeks of illness, some people experience post-COVID conditions. Post-COVID conditions are a wide range of new, returning, or ongoing health problems people can experience more than four weeks after first being infected with the virus that causes COVID-19. Even people who did not have symptoms when they were infected can have post-COVID conditions. These conditions can have different types and combinations of health problems for different lengths of time.
The CDC and experts around the world are working to learn more about short- and long-term health effects associated with COVID-19, who gets them, and why.
Learn more from the CDC about post COVID conditions.

questionOriginal: What if there is a case of COVID-19 in school?
questionText: What if there is a case of COVID-19 in school?
answerOriginal:
The Health Department quickly responds every time we receive a positive test result for COVID-19. A contact tracer calls the person who tested positive (or their parent) within 24 hours, asks them questions about their recent activities and who theyâve been in contact with during their infectious period, and gives instructions on staying home. The team contacts the school if the person was there while infectious. Schools do not need to take action if someone with COVID-19 was not at the school during their infectious period.

The Health Department will:

  • Work closely with the school and ask about who had close contact (within 6 feet for at least 15 minutes) with the person with COVID-19 while they were infectious, like classmates and teachers. Information that identifies the individual will only be shared if consent was given.
  • Reach out to all people with close contact and give them information about quarantine and testing.
  • Discuss next steps with school administration, including whether to temporarily move to remote instruction.

The school will:

  • Close off any areas where the person spent longer than 15 minutes (like a classroom, gym, or a cafeteria) then clean and disinfect the areas.
  • Communicate with parents and staff about the situation, and encourage everyone to answer calls from the Health Department for contact tracing, if they get called. Contact tracers only call the people who our infectious disease experts determine have had close contact with a person with COVID-19 while they were infectious.
  • Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces in the school.
  • Make sure that anyone who tests positive for COVID-19 stays home from school (isolation) until they can return.
  • Make sure that anyone who had close contact with someone with COVID-19 while they were infectious stays home from school (quarantine) until they can return. Someone under quarantine does not have COVID-19 and cannot pass it to others, but they may become infected within 14 days.

Learn more about the Health Department's response to COVID-19 cases.

Several resources for school administrators, nurses and COVID coordinators are available on the Health Department School web page including a quick reference guide for when someone with COVID-19 was at school while infectious.

You can learn more about that and other information about what parents can expect for pre-K through 12th grade as schools reopen for the fall.
answerText:
The Health Department responds every time we receive a positive test result for COVID-19.
The Health Department will:

Contact the person who tested positive (or their parent/guardian), ask them questions about their recent activities and who theyâve been inÂ close contactÂ with, and give instructions on staying home.
Notify the school if the person who tested positive is associated with a school.
Schools do not need toÂ take actionÂ if the Health Department determines that there is no risk of further spread at the school. For example, if the person with COVID-19 was not at school during their infectious period, there would not have been an opportunity to spread the virus to others at school.
Work closely with the school to identifyÂ people atÂ theÂ school who hadÂ close contactÂ (within 6 feet for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period)Â withÂ aÂ person with COVID-19 during theirÂ infectious period, including duringÂ high-risk activities.

The school will:

Follow theÂ Checklist for Handling COVID-19 in SchoolsÂ and collaborate with the Health Department on the investigation.
CleanÂ and disinfectÂ any areas where the person spent longer than 15 minutes (like a classroom, gym, or a cafeteria), especially high-touch surfaces.

For more information:

Learn more about the Health Department's response to COVID-19 cases.

questionOriginal: What do I do if I test positive for COVID-19?
questionText: What do I do if I test positive for COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Most people with mild illness can recover at home. While there is no specific treatment for COVID-19, you should get plenty of rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take fever-reducing medication if needed.

If you or a family member are sick, follow these steps to care for yourself and to help protect other people in your home and your community:

Isolate at home

  • Stay home, except to get medical care. Call ahead before visiting your health care provider. Anyone who does not have a health care provider can call 2-1-1 to be connected to care or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics.
  • Separate yourself from other people and pets**.**
  • Monitor your symptoms.
  • Wear a face mask or covering when you're around people and pets.
  • Cover your coughs and sneezes with your sleeve or a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
  • Wash your hands often. Use an alcohol-based sanitizer if soap and water aren't available.
  • Avoid sharing personal household items**.**
  • Clean all high-touch surfaces in your home daily.
  • Get support from others. Stay in touch with family and friends by phone, email or online platform.

Someone from the Health Department will contact you to ask for your help with contact tracing. Contact tracing is used to provide education, support and guidance to people who are diagnosed with an infectious disease. Itâs also used to identify people who have been in close contact with them, so they can take steps to stop the disease from spreading to others.

Learn more:

  • Caring for yourself at home from the CDC
  • 10 ways to manage respiratory symptoms at home from the CDC
  • Information on breastfeeding if you have COVID-19 from the CDC
  • What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation
  • What to do if you test positive for COVID-19
answerText:
You will need to isolate if you test positive for COVID-19. Isolation means you need to stay home and away from other people, until you have recovered. This is to prevent further spread of the virus.
Most people with mild illness can recover at home. While there is no specific treatment for COVID-19, you should get plenty of rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take fever-reducing medication if needed.
A contact tracer will call you to give you guidance. They will answer any questions you may have and see if you need help getting resources to stay home.
Learn more about what to do if you test positive for COVID-19.
Learn more from the CDC:

What to do if you are sick
10 things you can do to manage your COVID-19 symptoms at home

questionOriginal: Are bars and restaurants open?
questionText: Are bars and restaurants open?
answerOriginal:
On April 10, the Governor extended his order (effective Tuesday, March 17 at 2 p.m.) closing all bars and restaurants statewide until May 15.

Establishments can continue to offer food take out and delivery.

Find up-to-date guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements for bars, restaurants and food service from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD), which requires employees to wear non-medical cloth face masks or coverings (bandanna, scarf, or non-medical mask, etc.) over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.

Find more health resources for businesses and read the Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses.

The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.
answerText: Restaurants, catering, food service, social clubs and bars are open and following universal guidance. They are required to close at 10 p.m. every night.

questionOriginal: How are children affected by the COVID-19 virus?
questionText: How are children affected by the COVID-19 virus?
answerOriginal:
According to the CDC, while fewer children have been sick with COVID-19 compared to adults, children can be infected with the COVID-19 virus, can get sick from COVID-19, and can spread the virus to others. Children, like adults, who have COVID-19 but have no symptoms can still spread the virus to others.

Most children with COVID-19 have mild symptoms or have no symptoms at all. However, some children can get severely ill from COVID-19. They might require hospitalization, intensive care, or a ventilator to help them breathe. In rare cases, they might die. Babies under 1 year old and children with certain underlying conditions may be more likely to have severe illness from COVID-19. Learn more from the CDC about COVID-19 in children and teens.

A few children have developed Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C). Currently, information about MIS-C is limited, and the CDC is working to learn more.

You can find information about cases across age groups along with other COVID-19 data on the Vermont Dashboard. More detailed information is in the Weekly Data Summaries, which include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What do I need to do if I am traveling internationally?
questionText: What do I need to do if I am traveling internationally?

Visit the CDCâs travel page for travel recommendations by country and see the FAQs for Travelers.

Check CDCâs travel notices for Canada and read Canadaâs entry restrictions for current information about travel to or from Canada.

The CDC recommends no one travel on cruise ships, including river cruises, worldwide, especially people with an increased risk of serious illness. Thatâs because the risk of COVID-19 on cruise ships is high. Learn more about cruise ships and river cruise voyages.

You must follow travel restrictions and quarantine requirements for the countries you plan to visit.

International travelers can get tested in Vermont for free. Learn more about getting tested for COVID-19.

Follow the CDCâs "after international travelâ guidance when you enter the U.S.

questionOriginal: Iâm 16 or 17. What do I need to know about getting my vaccine?
questionText: Iâm 16 or 17. What do I need to know about getting my vaccine?
answerOriginal:
If you are making an appointment through the Health Department website, youâll need to create an account. Either you can create your own account, or your parent or guardian can add you as a dependent on their account.

When you make your appointment, you will only see appointments for the Pfizer vaccine since that is the only vaccine that is authorized for people age 16 and 17. Sometimes you may need to look at neighboring counties if nothing comes up in your county.

Your parent or guardian will need to review the consent forms and check the box giving their consent for you to get the vaccine. Since the consent is built into the registration process, your parent or guardian will not need to go with you to your appointment.

If you are making an appointment directly through Walgreens, your parent or guardian will need to go with you to your appointment and give their consent.
answerText:
If you are making an appointment through the Health Department website, youâll need to create an account. Either you can create your own account, or your parent or guardian can add you as a dependent on their account.
When you make your appointment through the Health Department website, you will only see appointments for the Pfizer vaccine since that is the only vaccine that is authorized for people age 12 to 17.
Certain pharmacies, including CVS and Kinney Drugs, are also offering the Pfizer vaccine to your age group, and some have walk-in opportunities.
For the appointments made through the Health Department website and through CVS, you will either need to:

Make an appointment through the website or
Come to get your vaccine with a parent or guardian who can give consent or
Come to get your vaccine with a completed consent form and completed prevaccination checklist

Some of the school-located vaccine clinics have other ways of making sure consent is given, and you can learn about that from your school or school district.
If you are making an appointment directly through Walgreens, your parent or guardian will need to go with you to your appointment and give their consent.

questionOriginal: How does COVID-19 spread?
questionText: How does COVID-19 spread?
answerOriginal:
The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person.

  • Between people who are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet).

  • Through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs, sneezes or talks.

  • These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs.

  • Some recent studies have suggested that COVID-19 may be spread by people who are not showing symptoms.

It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

Learn from the CDC how to help prevent spread of the virus and how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.
answerText:
COVID-19 spreads when a person infected with COVID-19 breathes out droplets and very small particles that contain the virus when they cough, sneeze, sing, talk, or breathe. People who are closer than 6 feet from the person with COVID-19 are most likely to get infected.
You can get COVID-19 if these droplets and particles:

are breathed in,
land on your eyes, nose, or mouth or
get on your hands, and then you touch your eyes, nose or mouth.

To protect yourself from getting COVID-19:

Get the COVID-19 vaccine.
Wear a mask.
Stay at least 6 feet apart.
Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.
Gather outside.
Wash your hands.

Find more information and frequently asked questions from the CDC about:

Ways COVID-19 Spreads
Food and water
Pools, hot tubs and water playgrounds
Pets and animals

questionOriginal: Do I have to be a Vermont resident to get the COVID-19 vaccine?
questionText: Do I have to be a Vermont resident to get the COVID-19 vaccine?
answerOriginal:
Yes. You will need to provide your address to make an appointment for the COVID-19 vaccine. However, if you live in another state, you can still get a vaccine in Vermont if:

  • You work in Vermont.
  • Your primary health care provider is in Vermont.
  • You moved to Vermont within the last 6 months with the intention of becoming a resident.

Identification is not required to make or go to a vaccine appointment.

People who are 75 years and older and live, work, or access primary health care in Vermont are now eligible to get a vaccine. Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

Find out who will be eligible next.
answerText:
No. Anyone age 12 and older who lives in Vermont or is visiting Vermont, can get vaccinated. You do not have to be a Vermont resident or a part-time resident.
Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

questionOriginal: Do I need to bring identification to my vaccine appointment?
questionText: Do I need to bring identification to my vaccine appointment?
answerOriginal:

When you sign up for your appointment, you will be asked to provide your:

  • Name
  • Date of birth
  • Address
  • Email (if available)
  • Phone number
  • Health insurance information (helpful but not required)

Learn more about if you are not a Vermont resident.

No. Identification is not required to make your vaccine appointment, and you don't need to bring an ID with you to your appointment.
If you are getting a Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccine, we recommend bringing your vaccine card to your second dose appointment, but it is not required.

Date of birth
Address

questionOriginal: Why canât children under 12 get the COVID-19 vaccine?
questionText: Why canât children under 12 get the COVID-19 vaccine?
answerOriginal:
Childrenâs immune systems are different at different ages. They are also different from adults. This means that the vaccine studies need to be repeated with children.

Vermont is now vaccinating 12- to 15-year-olds, following the approval of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine for emergency use in this age group. Learn more about vaccinating 12- to 15-year-olds.

Moderna and Johnson & Johnson are each running clinical vaccine trials with adolescents aged 12 to 17. Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna have clinical trials of their vaccines for younger children going on now.

If the trials are successful, there will be the usual review processes before the vaccines can be approved for emergency use and then produced for distribution. This process can take a while, especially for very young ages, which are usually tested last.

  • The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is authorized for people 12 years and older.
  • The Moderna vaccine is authorized for people 18 years and older.
  • The Johnson & Johnson (Janssen) vaccine is authorized for people 18 years and older.

Find out what 12 to 17-year-olds need to do to get vaccinated.
answerText:
Childrenâs immune systems are different at different ages. They are also different from adults. This means that the vaccine studies need to be repeated with children.
Vermont is now vaccinating 12- to 15-year-olds, following the approval of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine for emergency use in this age group. Learn more about vaccinating 12- to 15-year-olds.
Moderna and Johnson & Johnson are each running clinical vaccine trials with adolescents aged 12 to 17. Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna have clinical trials of their vaccines for younger children going on now.
If the trials are successful, there will be the usual review processes before the vaccines can be approved for emergency use and then produced for distribution. This process can take a while, especially for very young ages, which are usually tested last.

The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is authorized for people 12 years and older.
The Moderna vaccine is authorized for people 18 years and older.
The Johnson & Johnson (Janssen) vaccine is authorized for people 18 years and older.

Find out what 12 to 17-year-olds need to do to get vaccinated.

questionOriginal: How can I help protect myself from getting the virus?
questionText: How can I help protect myself from getting the virus?
answerOriginal:
The best way to prevent yourself and others from getting sick with COVID-19 is to avoid being exposed to the virus. The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. Everyone should:

  • Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after being in a public place, before eating, and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.

  • If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Cover all surfaces of your hands and rub them together until they feel dry.

  • Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.

  • Stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.

  • Avoid close contact with people who are sick.

  • Wear a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain. For example, at a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.

  • Stay home when you are sick.

  • Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue or the inside of your elbow. Throw used tissues in the trash. Then immediately wash your hands with soap and water or use an alcohol-based sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.

  • Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily.

Learn more about COVID-19 prevention and how to protect yourself and others.
answerText:
The virus is thought to spread mainly through close contact from person to person. Here is how you can protect yourself from getting COVID-19 and from spreading it to others:

Get the COVID-19 vaccine.
Stay home and away from others if you are sick.
Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol, especially after being in a public place, before eating, and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.
Take care when getting together. Gather outside and follow Vermontâs gathering limits.
Have the âThe COVID Talkâ with people before you make plans and share what you need to feel safe and comfortable.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with if you are unvaccinated.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with if you are unvaccinated.
Avoid crowded indoor spaces.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue or the inside of your elbow. Throw the tissue in the trash and wash your hands or use hand sanitizer.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily.
Limit your travel. The CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Can I make a vaccine appointment for someone else (for example a family member, someone who lives with you, or a client)?
questionText: Can I make a vaccine appointment for someone else (for example a family member, someone who lives with you, or a client)?
answerOriginal:
Yes. You can make an appointment for a family member, someone who lives with you, someone you care for, or a client.

If you are scheduling an appointment for someone else, we recommend that you create an account, and then sign them up under your account as a âdependent/household member/client.â Below are the step-by-step instructions. You can also watch a video on how to make an appointment online and find tips for making an appointment.

If you would like to make an appointment for someone at the same time as your own, you will need to make the appointments individually. Learn more about making two appointments at the same time.

Anyone who is unable to make their appointment online, needs help, or who wants to speak with someone in a language other than English can call 855-722-7878 and press 1 for interpretation services, Monday through Friday from 8:15 a.m. â 5:30 p.m., Saturday and Sunday from 10:00 a.m. â 3:00 p.m. This phone line is TTY enabled.

1. Create an account.

First, you will need to create an account in our online system. You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address.

If you already have an account because you were tested for COVID-19 through a Health Department site, you need to use the same account information to schedule an appointment to get a vaccine. The system will not allow you to create a new account if you use an email address that is already in the system.

If you already have an account, start at the âadd a dependent/household member/clientâ step below.

Here is how you create an account:

  • Go to the COVID-19 Event Portal.
  • Enter your name, phone number, email address, and date of birth.
  • Click the âcreate accountâ button.

After you create an account, an email is immediately sent to the email address you entered. You will need to verify your account on the COVID-19 Event Portal to make the personâs appointment:

  • Click on the link in the email sent to you to confirm your account.
  • Enter your Patient ID number.
  • Enter your email and date of birth.
  • Create a password.
  • Review and consent to the Notice of Privacy Practices.
  • Enter your personal demographic information.
  • Enter your vaccine eligibility information, including your passcode (if applicable).

2. Add a dependent/household member/client.

You will need to add them to your account. You can watch a video on how to add a dependent to your account. Click on the âAdd Dependent/Household Member/Clientâ button at the top of the screen. After consenting, you will need to enter their personal information:

  • Name
  • Email address (use your email, the same one used to set up your account)
  • Phone number
  • Select how you would like to receive communication and documents from the Health Department.
  • Date of birth
  • Address
  • Enter their vaccine eligibility information, including their passcode (if applicable).

If the person getting the vaccine does not live in Vermont, the system will ask do they work in Vermont or recently moved to Vermont. If none of these apply, they wonât be able to get vaccinated in Vermont, and should seek a vaccine in the state where they live.

3. Schedule a vaccine appointment.

Click the âSchedule Vaccine Appointmentâ button at the top of the screen and select their name. Select a clinic site location by searching by county and date range.

Next, you will answer a series of medical (see below) and demographic questions as well as questions about any COVID-19 symptoms the person has. You also will be asked to complete a waiver.

Finally, choose an appointment slot from the list of available appointments. Click the âsubmitâ button. You may be redirected to choose a different location and time depending on their vaccine eligibility. Once you make an appointment, you will immediately receive an email confirmation.

These are the medical screening questions asked:

  1. Have you had a severe allergic reaction (e.g., anaphylaxis) after a previous dose of the Pfizer or Moderna COVID-19 vaccine or any of its components? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get a vaccine. They should consider contacting their health care provider if they have questions.
  2. Have you had an immediate allergic reaction to any other vaccine or injectable therapy? If the answer is yes, then they will be asked to contact their health care provider for a referral to an allergy/immunology specialist who can determine if they can safely receive the vaccine.
  3. Are you currently sick with COVID-19 or still in your isolation period following a COVID-19 infection? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get a COVID-19 vaccine at this time, but can schedule an appointment at a later date.
  4. Have you had a vaccine in the past 14 days or is a vaccination scheduled in the next 8 weeks? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get a COVID-19 vaccine at this time, but can schedule an appointment at a later date.
  5. Have you received passive antibody therapy as treatment for COVID-19 in the past 90 days? If the answer is yes, then they will need to wait for 90 days before scheduling an appointment.
  6. Do you have a weakened immune system caused by something such as HIV infection or cancer or do you take immunosuppressive drugs or therapies? If the answer is yes, they can make an appointment, but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
  7. Are you lactating or breastfeeding? If the answer is yes, they can make an appointment, but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.

questionOriginal: What should older adults and people with certain medical conditions do?
questionText: What should older adults and people with certain medical conditions do?
answerOriginal:
Getting vaccinated is the best way to protect yourself from getting COVID-19. If you have a condition or are taking medications that weaken your immune system, you may not be fully protected even if you are fully vaccinated. Talk to your health care provider. Even after vaccination, you may need to continue taking all precautions.

According to the CDC, the risk for severe illness from COVID-19 increases with age, with older adults at highest risk. Certain medical conditions can also increase the risk for severe illness. Severe illness means that the person with COVID-19 may require hospitalization, intensive care, or a ventilator to help them breathe, or they may even die.

The CDC recommends other people at increased risk also take extra precautions, like pregnant people, people experiencing homelessness, and people with disabilities.

questionOriginal: Are face masks or coverings required in Vermont?
questionText: Are face masks or coverings required in Vermont?
answerOriginal:
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part your household. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces and group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes).

Face masks or coverings are not required when you are doing strenuous exercise or activities. They are also not required for â and should not be worn by:

  • Children under the age of 2
  • Anyone who has trouble breathing
  • Anyone who is unable to remove the face mask without assistance
  • Anyone who has a medical or behavioral reason for not wearing a face mask

If you have a medical or developmental condition or have trouble breathing, you are not required to show evidence or documentation of your condition.

Businesses and other entities may also post signage explaining their mask requirements and can deny entry or service to people who do not to wear a mask.

Wearing face masks or coverings helps keep people from spreading the virus. This is because the virus can spread even if a person does not have any symptoms.

In addition to wearing cloth face masks or coverings, everyone should keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash their hands often, and stay home if they are sick.

Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19 and face coverings for children.
answerText:
Requirements have changed effective May 14, 2021. However, it is important to remember that people with COVID-19 can spread the virus even if they donât have any symptoms. Wearing a mask protects both you and the people around you from getting or spreading COVID-19.
If You Are Fully Vaccinated
Anyone who is fully vaccinated is not required to wear a mask or maintain a 6-foot distance from others. You are fully vaccinated 14 days after your final shot.
There are some exceptions, and you will need to wear a mask in schools, health care settings, long-term care facilities, correctional facilities and on public transportation. Businesses or municipalities can also require you to wear a mask if they choose to do so.
If You Are Unvaccinated or Partially Vaccinated (including children)
These individuals must follow the current mask requirements:
1. INDOORS: You are required to wear a face mask or covering in indoor public spaces in Vermont. Indoor public spaces include businesses, public buildings, and group living settings (such as long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes).
In indoor private settings, we recommend that you wear a mask anytime people who are not fully vaccinated get together (for example, at a gathering with family and friends or riding in a car). Check the current limits on gatherings and events.
2. OUTDOORS: When you are outdoors, masks are only required when you are in a crowd or with multiple other households where you canât maintain a 6-foot distance.
Vermonters can decide whether they need a mask by considering three elements:

Outside
Masked
Distanced

You need two of these three elements. For example â if youâre outside and distanced, you donât need a mask. If youâre outside and not distanced, wear a mask. And if youâre not outside, you should wear a mask and keep a distance.
Masks are not required when you are doing strenuous exercise or activities. They are also not required for â and should not be worn by:

Children under the age of 2
Anyone who has trouble breathing
Anyone who is unable to remove the face mask without assistance
Anyone who has a medical or behavioral reason for not wearing a face mask

If you have a medical or developmental condition or have trouble breathing, you are not required to show evidence or documentation of your condition.
Businesses and other entities may also post signage explaining their mask requirements and can deny entry or service to people who are not wearing a mask, including people who are not required to wear a mask. However, the business must provide another way for people who are unable to wear a mask to access the business (for example, offering curbside pick-up or delivery or other creative solution).
The CDC requires everyone to wear masks when using public transportation.
In addition to wearing masks, continue to follow the prevention steps like keeping 6 feet apart and washing your hands often.
Learn more:

Wearing face masks to keep COVID-19 from spreading
CDCâs guide to masks â how to choose, wear, store and wash masks

The State of Vermont is offering a limited number of free cloth masks to the public. Find out if free cloth masks are available in your area.

questionOriginal: Do I need to quarantine if I live with someone or had close contact with someone who is under quarantine?
questionText: Do I need to quarantine if I live with someone or had close contact with someone who is under quarantine?
answerOriginal:
No. You do not need to quarantine if you had close contact with someone who is under quarantine. That means you can go to school, work, or the grocery store.

If you are living with someone who is under quarantine, stay at least 6 feet from them. People under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with others in the household who are not under quarantine. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.
answerText:
Yes. You will need to quarantine if you are a close contact or live with someone who tests positive for COVID-19 (unless you are fully vaccinated or recently had COVID-19). If you are identified as a close contact, you will be contacted. This is known as contact tracing. The notification will come from the Health Department or a place you went to recently (for example, your employer, your childâs school, or your health care provider might contact you). They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time.
Learn more about what to expect from contact tracing.
Find tips about quarantining when you share a home.

questionOriginal: I have a high-risk health condition. How do I make an appointment for a vaccine?
questionText: I have a high-risk health condition. How do I make an appointment for a vaccine?
answerOriginal:
There are certain medical conditions that put people at increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19 as identified by the CDC. If you have a high-risk health condition (listed below), you do not need to contact your health care provider to get documentation of the condition.

You will make an appointment in our system in the same way as Vermonters who have been eligible by age.

You will be asked some questions. First, you will say that you have one of the health conditions that makes you eligible for a vaccine. This will serve as a self-certification. We trust you to work with us and help make sure that these Vermonters at highest risk due to a medical condition are protected.

When making your appointment, you will also be asked to provide information for a health care provider you see for the condition, if you have one. But if you donât have a health care provider, you can still get a vaccine.

The Health Department may use the information you provided to confirm your eligibility, either through medical records or by contacting your provider. We may also reach out to people who donât have a provider to offer a connection to care.

Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

The high-risk health conditions are:

  • Current cancer
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • COPD, including emphysema and chronic bronchitis
  • Heart disease, including heart attack, heart failure, congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease (angina, acute and chronic ischemic heart disease), cardiomyopathies, and pulmonary hypertension. Does NOT include high blood pressure.
  • Immunocompromised (weakened immune system), due to solid organ transplant, blood, or bone marrow transplant, immune deficiencies, or other causes; or HIV with a low CD4 cell count or not on HIV treatment; prolonged use of corticosteroids or other immune-suppressing drugs.
  • Severe obesity (BMI of 40 or above)
  • Pregnancy
  • Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes
  • Disabilities including chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome; intellectual disabilities (IQ of 70 or below); disabilities that compromise lung function (neurologic and muscular conditions such as muscular dystrophy, spina bifida, and multiple sclerosis)
  • Sickle cell disease
answerText:
There are enough appointments for everyone. Generally, appointments are required, although some clinics may be able to accept walk-ins. When that happens, we will share that information on our website and on our @healthvermont social media channels.
Already have an account set up? Log in to your account to make an appointment.
Anyone who is unable to make their appointment online, needs help, or who wants to speak with someone in a language other than English can call 855-722-7878. This phone line is TTY enabled.
You can also make an appointment directly through Kinney Drugs, CVS, Walgreens, Northfield Pharmacy or UVMMC Outpatient Pharmacies.
Create an Account
You will need to create an account in our online system first, and then log in to schedule your appointment.
You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address.
If you already have an account because you were tested for COVID-19 through a Health Department site, you need to use the same account information to schedule an appointment to get a vaccine. The online system will not allow you to create a new account if you use an email address that is already in the system.
Create an account.
Make a Vaccine Appointment
The name of the vaccine offered at the clinic is listed after the âeventâ description. However, there is no way to search for an appointment based on which vaccine is available.
Some vaccine clinics are drive-through clinics. If they are, you will see âDrive Thruâ listed in the âeventâ description.
You can find a different appointment or adjust other appointment search criteria without losing your information. Click âCANCELâ to leave the âSchedule Appointmentâ screen, click on âSearch Eventâ in the menu to the left, change your search criteria, and then click âSchedule Appointmentâ to jump back to where you were.
Make a vaccine appointment.
You can also watch videos on how to:

make your vaccine appointment online
add a dependent or spouse to your account

Talk with your health care provider if you've had an immediate allergic reaction to any other vaccine, injectable therapy, or polysorbate, or if you have questions about whether getting the vaccine is right for you because of health conditions, allergies, or other vaccines you've received recently. Read the health screening questions asked before you get the vaccine.

Tips for making a vaccine appointment
How to make a vaccine appointment for someone else
What to do if you have problems scheduling a vaccine appointment
What to expect at your vaccine appointment
Frequently asked questions about vaccine registration and appointments

questionOriginal: How many people can be at a gathering or event?
questionText: How many people can be at a gathering or event?
answerOriginal:
Vermont has limits on social gatherings and events based on whether you are fully vaccinated or not. You are fully vaccinated 14 days after your final shot. Since children under age 12 cannot get vaccinated at this time, they are considered unvaccinated.

As of May 14, the following limits apply to gatherings in both public and private settings (for example, an event at a venue or a gathering at a home). If you donât know if someone is fully vaccinated, then assume everyone is unvaccinated and follow that guidance. Find out when the limits will change again.

For indoor gatherings:

There can be one unvaccinated person per 50 square feet up to 300 unvaccinated people (whichever is less), plus any number of fully vaccinated people.

For outdoor gatherings:

There can be 900 unvaccinated people, plus any number of fully vaccinated people.

If you are a visitor traveling to Vermont and staying at a lodging establishment, short-term rental, or with friends and family, you must follow the gathering limits. Staying with another household is considered a social gathering and you must follow the rules listed above.

Check the current mask requirements.

Find tips from the CDC:

  • Holiday celebrations
  • Hosting gatherings or cook-outs
  • Attending an event or gathering

questionOriginal: Are sports and outdoor activities allowed?
questionText: Are sports and outdoor activities allowed?
answerOriginal:
We encourage Vermonters to go outside and enjoy the fresh air. Exercise, outdoor activities, and taking in Vermontâs natural beauty is important for our mind and bodies.

Businesses, non-profit and government entities that support or offer outdoor recreation and outdoor fitness activities with low or no direct physical contact can open on May 7. These include, but are not limited to, state and municipal parks, recreation associations, trail networks, golf courses, big game check stations and guided expeditions.

Campgrounds, marinas and beaches are not permitted to open at this time. Find up-to-date information on outdoor recreation and campgrounds from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development.

Contact sports and games should not be played at this time.

We can safely continue to enjoy outdoor activities with these measures:

  • Stay close to home. Find local outdoor recreation areas and consider day trips that are close to home. Only drive with members of your household.

  • Take health and safety precautions. Keep the virus from spreading by staying at least 6 feet apart from other people outside of your household, washing or sanitizing your hands, and staying home when you are sick.

  • Bring a cloth face mask with you. Put a cloth face mask or covering on if you encounter other people and stop to chat or if you are on a crowded trail or bike path.

  • Be cautious and choose low-risk activities to avoid injury. This will help lower the burden on our hospitals and health care system.

  • Respect signs for closed areas, trails and land. Check Trail Finder to find out if your trail is currently open before you visit. Call ahead or check websites for information on outdoor recreation facilities before you head out.

  • Choose no-contact sports: For example, biking, hiking, horseback riding, tennis, boating and golfing. Outdoor basketball courts may be open to shoot hoops, but signage should be posted prohibiting contact games. Do not share sports equipment with people outside of your household.

  • Check for ticks and wear an EPA-registered tick repellent. When youâre out walking or spending time in your backyard, remember that ticks are active this time of year. Find out how to Be Tick Smart and prevent tick bites.

Find out more about outdoor recreation and COVID-19 from the Vermont Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation and the Vermont Fish and Wildlife Department.

Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.
answerText:
Yes. You can do outdoor recreation and fitness activities with anyone. In public outdoor spaces, masks are only required when you are in a crowd or with multiple other households where you canât maintain a 6-foot distance, whether you are vaccinated or not.
Businesses, facilities and organizations that support or offer outdoor recreation and outdoor fitness activities are following universal guidance.
Sports and organized sports (including youth leagues, adult leagues, practices, games and tournaments) are following specialized guidance. School sports are followingÂ the school-based sports program guidance.
Find out more about outdoor recreation and COVID-19 from the Vermont Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation and the Vermont Fish and Wildlife Department.

questionOriginal: Can we still have our wedding ceremony?
questionText: Can we still have our wedding ceremony?
answerOriginal:
At this time, marriage ceremonies are discouraged, and officiants must ask to postpone services. But if a ceremony is held, it must be in accordance with the governorâs orders. This includes limiting gatherings to fewer than 10 people in the same space at the same time.

Visitors from other states and countries are asked not to come to Vermont at this time. If they do come to Vermont, they must stay at home (quarantine) 14 days before participating in any activities out of their home or lodging.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

Learn more about quarantine on the what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation chart.

However, there are some exceptions, and this guidance may change. Find up-to-date information on marriage ceremonies from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development.
answerText:
You can get a marriage license from Vermont town offices. Check with the town office on how to get your license since they may be operating remotely or offering curbside service.
Event venues are following universal guidance. Check the current limits on gatherings and events.
Have your ceremony outdoors whenever possible. Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading or getting COVID-19. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Where can I get vaccinated?
questionText: Where can I get vaccinated?
answerOriginal:
You can find a map of the areas where vaccination sites are, not actual locations. When you schedule your appointment, you will get the address of the vaccination site you chose. People 65 years and older can make an appointment online or by phone. Find out what you will need and how to make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

Health care personnel and long-term care residents and staff can find out how to get a vaccine appointment.

For each phase, we will offer vaccines at regional clinics set up by the state. These clinics will be handicapped accessible. Some vaccines will be available through our partner hospitals, providers, and pharmacies.

Vaccines will be available to people who are homebound through a partnership with home health agencies and EMS.

We are also collaborating with community organizations and other partners to make sure people who are disproportionately affected by COVID-19, including Black, Indigenous and people of color, have equitable access to the vaccine.
answerText:
There are many vaccination sites across the state. Generally, appointments are required, although some clinics may be able to accept walk-ins. When that happens, we will share that information on our website and on our @healthvermont social media channels.
You can make an appointment for a clinic or pharmacy near you through the Health Department website. This includes clinics run by the Health Department, the National Guard, health care partners, Costco, Hannaford, Price Chopper, Rite Aid, Shaws and Walmart (please do not call the stores directly). Make an appointment.
If you would like to make an appointment for a Kinney Drugs, CVS, Walgreens, Northfield Pharmacy or UVMMC Outpatient Pharmacy near you, you can make an appointment directly through their websites. Make an appointment with Kinney Drugs, CVS, Walgreens, Northfield Pharmacy or UVMMC Outpatient Pharmacies.

questionOriginal: What can I do after I am fully vaccinated?
questionText: What can I do after I am fully vaccinated?
answerOriginal:
You are fully vaccinated 14 days after your final shot. Until you are fully vaccinated, you should follow the same guidance as unvaccinated people. Learn about why it is important to get two doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccine.

Continue Prevention

Continue takingÂ steps to prevent COVID-19, except as described below.

The vaccine protects you from illness, but we donât know for sure if you can give the virus to someone else. Some recent studies suggest that a person who is vaccinated is less likely to infect other people with the COVID-19 virus. Until enough people are vaccinated and we know more, it is important to continue to follow prevention steps and continue to wear a mask, keep 6 feet apart, and wash your hands.

Gathering with Others

The following guidance only applies in non-health care settings.

  • You may gather with other fully vaccinated people indoors without wearing masks or staying 6 feet apart.
  • You may also gather with unvaccinated people from one household indoors without wearing masks or staying 6 feet apart, as long as everyone in that household is at low risk for severe COVID-19.

If you gather with people from more than one unvaccinated household, or with someone who is at higher risk of severe COVID-19, you must wear a mask and keep a 6-foot distance. SeeÂ details on gathering restrictions in Vermont.

Travel

You may travel to or return to Vermont without quarantine. Find outÂ more about travel, includingÂ staying in someone's home.

Close Contact of Someone with COVID-19

If you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19, as long as you do not have symptoms and are not in a health care setting:

  • You do not need to seek testing.
  • You do not need to quarantine.
answerText:
You are fully vaccinated 14 days after your final shot. However, if you have a condition or take medications that weaken your immune system, you may not be fully protected even if you are fully vaccinated. Talk to your health care provider about whether you should continue taking all precautions.
Until you are fully vaccinated, you should follow the same guidance as unvaccinated people. Learn about why it is important to get two doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccine.
Health care settings may follow separate guidance. Read CDC's guidance for health care workers.
Prevention Steps
You do not need to wear a mask or stay 6 feet apart. There are some exceptions, and you will need to wear a mask in schools, health care settings, long-term care facilities, correctional facilities and on public transportation. Businesses or municipalities can also require you to wear a mask.
Continue taking other steps to prevent COVID-19, like staying home when you are sick and washing your hands. You should still watch out for symptoms of COVID-19, especially if youâve been around someone who is sick. If you have symptoms of COVID-19, you should call your health care provider to get tested and stay home and away from others.
Gathering with Others
Check the current limits on gatherings and events.
Travel
As part of Vermont's phased reopening plan, travel no longer requires testing or quarantine. Rules for international travel are different. Learn more about international travel.
Close Contact of Someone with COVID-19
If you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19, as long as you do not have symptoms and are not in a health care setting:

You do not need to seek testing.
You do not need to quarantine.

Learn more from the CDC about when youâve been fully vaccinated.

questionOriginal: Do I need to bring my negative test result or my vaccine card with me when I travel to Vermont?
questionText: Do I need to bring my negative test result or my vaccine card with me when I travel to Vermont?
answerOriginal:
Yes. You should bring a copy of your negative test result or your vaccine card with you and be prepared to show it when asked.

If you are staying at a lodging, camping or short-term rental property in Vermont, you must also self-certify that you meet certain conditions.

Find more travel information for visitors to Vermont.
answerText: If you are fully vaccinated, be sure to carry your COVID-19 vaccine card with you and be prepared to show it when asked.

questionOriginal: How soon after being exposed to someone with COVID-19 should I get tested if I'm not fully vaccinated?
questionText: How soon after being exposed to someone with COVID-19 should I get tested if I'm not fully vaccinated?
answerOriginal:
The incubation period for the COVID-19 virus is 2 to 14 days. This means that it can take 2 to 14 days after being exposed to get symptoms or to test positive. If you are not fully vaccinated, you should get tested twice â as soon as 2 days after the exposure and again 7 days after the exposure if you:

  • think you have been exposed to someone with COVID-19 or
  • are a close contact.

For your initial test, if the result is negative, you will need to remain in quarantine and follow guidance provided by the Health Department. If the result is positive, you must follow isolation guidance provided by the Health Department.

Getting tested right away means you may be able to find out if you have COVID-19 early. This initial test also helps the Health Department find other people who have COVID-19 more quickly.

Getting tested before day 7 cannot be used to end quarantine early. Read about the option to end quarantine early by getting tested on day 7 or later. Learn about why it is okay to end quarantine early.

Check out this timeline for close contacts of people with COVID-19.

Find out what to do if you think you had close contact with someone who has COVID-19.
